loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 40 years old, married with 6 children. Two of her children are already married and have their homes whereas the rest are still in secondary and primary schools. Mercy has been the Treasurer of Kagaa Witeithie Women Group a position she has held since January 2005. She is trustworthy, a dedicated and hard working member of the group. Mercy has a retail shop at Ngurweini trading center. She sells maize flour, rice, sugar, and other household items. She also has a small farmland where she grows maize, beans and vegetables for home consumption and some for selling. In addition, she has a dairy cow and this gives her milk for sell as we as for home consumption. Most of her income comes from her retail shop and others supplement. Her monthly net income is about $73 and this is very low to support her family in future.

loans.use: Mercy wants to stock maize flour, wheat flour, rice, Soap, salt, Maize and beans.

loans.name: Aumaga

texts.en: Aumaga’s business is a taro plantation. With her previous loan, Aumaga extended her interest in not only developing her taro plantation, but also started growing vegetables. With a helping hand from her relatives, she built a small flea market stall for Aumaga to sell her products. Aumaga is a very loving person who welcomes anyone who wants to use her market stall to sell their taros, etc. Her loving support for other ladies in her village has inspired and encouraged them to start up their own small businesses. Now her business has become successful, and she’s applying for her next loan to buy organic fertilizers and pesticides for her taro plantation.

loans.use: Buy bags, organic fertilizers, and pesticides

loans.name: Nat

texts.en: Nat operates a taxi which runs everyday of the week and earns between 200 and 400 tala per day. (1 tala = $0.35 US dollars). The taxi is the main source of income for the family, and Nat needs finance to purchase spare tires for the taxi.

loans.use: To purchase tires

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa S. is twenty years old and has one child. She is married to a self-employed tailor. She runs her small market stall business in Magburaka town (Sierra Leone). She mainly sells sugar, onions and chicken stock cubes.

Hawa’s business income supplements her husband's income so her aim is to expand her business for more profit. Hawa is determined to help provide for her family. She is requesting this loan for the purpose of diversifying her inventory.

loans.use: To diversify the items she sells in her market stall business

loans.name: Alie

texts.en: Alie B. is forty-nine years old and married with five children.  He runs a business selling plastic sandals and clothes.  Alie says most of his income goes to his children’s education requirements and medical care.  Although the previous loan helped him increase his income, he now needs another loan of  $175 to allow him to further expand the business, especially to purchase more clothing for resale.

loans.use: Purchase more clothing for resale

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed is a 30-year-old single parent. He lost his wife a year ago and is now carrying the burden of taking care of the family alone. Mohamed says that his life was an easier one when his wife was alive because her business supplemented his income. Now life is hard for him. His small business is the only source of income and he has not been able to do much because he was taking care of their child.

Now his child has grown up a little and Mohamed has asked his mother and other members of his extended family to assist him in taking care of the child so that he can expand his business. Mohamed sells adult clothes in the town of Kabala, in Sierra Leone. He is requesting a loan of $275 for the purpose of expanding his business to generate more income.

loans.use: Expansion of his clothing business to generate additional income

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana Y. owns a general store in the Elmina market. She has been at this market for eight years but has been in the business for over 20 years now. Her store is special because she draws many customers with the palm oil that she sells. Palm oil is red and flavorful oil that is a key ingredient in many traditional Ghanaian dishes.

With her loan, Nana Y. hopes to purchase more palm oil as well as expand her stock in onions, tin tomatoes, and groundnuts. She will use the profits to support her three children who are all in school. Two are in middle school and one is in preschool.

Nana Y. is a member of the lending group, Nyame Beba of Elmina. The group members guarantee loans through a group repayment pledge. Peer support provides the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount. The members of this group have known each other for many years, and they all work in the market.

loans.use: Nana would use her loan to increase her stock of palm oil and add vegetables (onions and tomatoes) and groundnuts.

loans.name: Fernando

texts.es:
Fernando is a young man who has learned how to get ahead in spite of everything he has had to overcome. Some time ago, his father got terribly ill, and Fernando had to take charge of his business. This is where Fernando saw that the best way of making money was to be his own boss for himself and his family.

However, he doesn't have enough merchandise to offer his clients right now. This is why Fernando is requesting a loan of $375 that he is willing to repay in 6 months. With this money, he will be able to buy merchandise to be able to have something to offer his clients. With your help, Fernando will be able to get ahead and to support his family so they don't lack anything.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Fernando es un joven que a sabido salir adelante, a pesar de todo lo que a tenido que superar puesto que hace tiempo que su padre se enfermó terriblemente teniendose que ponerse a cargo del negocio Fernando, y ahí fue donde vio que la mejor manera de obtener dinero era siendo su propio dueño para él y para su familia.

Sin embargo actualmente no cuenta con suficiente mercancía para poder ofrecerle a sus clientes. Es por eso que Fernando está solicitando un crédito de US $375 que está dispuesto a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Fernando podrá comprar mercancía para poder tener algo que ofrecerle a sus clientes. Con tu ayuda Fernando podrá salir adelante para poder apoyar a su familia y que no les falte nada.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Luz Maria

texts.es:
Luz María is 40 years old. She had studied for a technical degree, but did not pursue a career because she married shortly thereafter and her husband did not want her to work. She has two children who still depend on her, and lives in the El Cortijo sector of the Trujillo province.

Luz started in the business of selling juices by traveling throughout the city. Subsequently, with the credit she received from Manuela Ramos, she added a display case in her house for cakes and bread. With both her savings, as well as later loans, she has outfitted her small store. She now has a well-stocked store in her home, and she continues with her sales of juices. She no longer travels around to sell her goods, but is instead able to do so from her own home.

She is a founding member of the collective bank “Luz Divina” (“Divine Light”) where she obtained her first loan of 300 soles (Peruvian currency). With the loan of 750 soles (approximately $275USD), to be repaid over six months, she will buy sodas, fruit and beer to sell in her store. Given that it is the summer season now, these products are in great demand.

Luz is very happy with what she has achieved, having initially suffered greatly at the hand of her husband. They are now separated, and she feels much better. She dreams of seeing her children succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Luz María tiene 40 años de edad, estudió una carrera técnica pero no la ejerció porque se casó al poco tiempo y su esposo no quería que trabaje. Tiene 2 hijos que aún dependen de ella y vive en el Sector El Cortijo, distrito de Trujillo, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad. La señora Luz se inicia en el negocio vendiendo jugos en un carrito el cual movilizaba por toda la ciudad, posteriormente con los créditos que recibió de Manuela Ramos puso en su casa un vitrina con algunos pasteles y pan. Ahorrando y con los siguientes créditos ha ido implementando su bodega, ahora tiene una bodega bien surtida en su casa y además no ha dejado el negocio de los jugos, pero ya no vende como ambulante sino en la puerta de su casa. Es socia fundadora del banco comunal “Luz Divina”, en su banco comunal obtuvo un primer crédito de S/. 300 con el cual compró vitrinas para iniciar la implementación de su bodega. Con el préstamo de S/.750, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará gaseosas, fruta y cerveza para vender en su bodega debido a que estamos en temporada de verano y estos productos tienen demanda. La señora Luz está muy contenta con lo que ha logrado, al inicio sufrió mucho porque su esposo la maltrataba pero decidió separarse y se siente mucho mejor. Sueña con ver a sus hijos realizados.

loans.use: Purchase sodas, fruit and beer to sell in general store.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel sells soft drinks in the town of Makeni in Sierra Leone.  His stock increased after accessing several small loans from SMT.  Samuel has saved some money from the profit and is requesting a Loan of $350. to purchase re-conditioned used refrigerators for the business.  Samuel is married, 38 years old, and has 2 children.

loans.use: Samuel wants to meet the summer time demand for cold drinks.  He needs the loan to purchase used refrigerators for his business.

loans.name: Mong

texts.en: Mrs. Mong I., 51, lives in Trapeang Chark Village, Kampong Cham province, where she earns $2.50 per day raising pigs and farming. Her husband Thon Tharn, 50, sells wood charcoal and earns $4 per day. They have three children, all of whom work in the garment industry where they each earn $50 per month. Mong I. requests a $500 loan to purchase more pigs to raise as well as buy more land to farm. They hope this loan will increase their business income, which in turn will help support their family.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to raise as well as buy more land to farm

loans.name: Bugolo Lending Group

texts.en:
Tausi N. is the chairperson of the Bugolo Lending Group in Kikondo, Lugazi. She is 42 years old and married with sx children, and also cares for two more kids. One of the children is an orphan and one is her step-child. They are both in school along with three of her kids.

Tausi's business is buying "mukene" (small silvery fish) from Kikondo to sell in the Tororo district. She's quick to say that the transport costs are worth it because each time she has to move she takes around 80 basins of fish, which she can buy for $400.00 and then sell for $500.00. She can't earn this profit margin if she is stationed at Kikondo in her area. She says the loans have really been helpful because she's been able to stop renting. She would now like a loan to expand her business and buy another plot for farming.

loans.use: Tausi would buy more basins of small fish to sell and buy a plot to farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To repair an old sewing machine and to purchase cloth and other materials.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok I. is married and lives with her husband in the outskirts of Phnom Penh. She has two children, who are students. Sok and her husband are farmers, normally earning around $4 each day. Recently the weather conditions have not been good, so the family has found it difficult to farm. To improve their standard of living, they plan to take out a loan to raise animals and purchase rice to make rice wine. These two businesses present a good opportunity that will lead to an improvement in their standard of living. Farmers like raising animals because it is easy to get income and spend less. Moreover, rice wine is very popular among Cambodia farmers. They like to drink rice wine because it cheap and not harmful to their health.

loans.use: To raise animals and purchase rice to make rice wine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in bras, shoes, girdles, and other goods to keep running her small business.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Mr. Sum S. is a villager in L'vea Sor Kandal Village in Kandal Province. He is a Khmer noodle maker and his wife, Mrs. Chhoem Sophy, is a Khmer noodle seller. Mr. Sum S. now faces a problem because his noodle machine is too old and it cannot make a good Khmer noodles for his customers. Thus, Mr. Sum S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a new Khmer noodle machine for his business. Mr. Sum S. is 54 years old and the father of seven children, two of whom are electricians while two are employed in a garment factory. The remaining three are attending school. His wife is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a new Khmer noodle machine for his business.

loans.name: Koffi Etsè Sénamé

texts.fr:
Né le 03 avril 1981 à Sansanné Mango dans la préfecture de l’Oti, Monsieur A. Koffi Etsè Sénamé vit actuellement à Aného où il fait son commerce de quincaillerie. Père de deux enfants, il a une boutique de quincaillerie dénommée Etablissement AVOCH & Fils.

Son emplacement dans la ville fait de lui le plus fréquenté. Avec une clientèle de plus en plus croissante, l’offre diminue par rapport à la demande. 

Pour être la hauteur de la demande et satisfaire sa clientèle, il sollicite un crédit pour ravitailler la boutique en quincaillerie.
texts.en:
Born on April 3, 1981 in Sansanné Mango in the Prefecture of Oti, Mr. Koffi Etsè Sénamé A. is presently living in Aného where he has his hardware business. The father of two children, he has a hardware store he calls Etablissement AVOCH & Fils.

His location in the town makes him easy to patronize. With his growing clientele, what he has to sell is gradually diminished by the demand for his goods.

In order to keep up with demand and satisfy the needs of his customers, he is asking for this loan to bolster the inventory of his hardware store.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of construction supplies

loans.name: Sylvie

texts.fr: Madame K. Sylvie est née en 1979 à Attiémé. Elle vit actuellement avec ses 2 enfants en charge à Afagnan. Instruite de niveau primaire, elle a vite cerné les rouages de son commerce. Elle achète les produits de première nécessité notamment les savons, les détergeants, du lait et autres à Lomé et les revend à Afagnan. Elle a besoin de financement pour augmenter la taille de son commerce et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Les bénéfices lui serviront à améliorer les conditions de vie des personnes à sa charge sur le plan scolaire, alimentaire et sanitaire.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sylvie K. was born in 1979 in Attiémé. She presently lives with her two children in Afagnan. She attended primary school, but quickly stepped out into the business world. She buys staples, especially soap, detergent, milk and other goods, in Lomé and re-sells them in Afagnan.

Sylvie needs a loan to expand the size of her business and better satisfy her clientele. She will use the profit to improve living conditions, from the standpoint of food and health concerns, for the children for whom she is the breadwinner and also to pay school fees.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of staple goods

loans.name: Juana

texts.es: Juana tiene 54 años, esta separada D. su pareja, vive con sus hijas, Irma  y Geraldine. Se dedica a la venta D. productos elaborados a base D. quinua, hornea tortas, galletas, etc. pero todo a base D. quinua, este producto andino con muchas propiedades alimenticias. A Juana le gusta hornear estos productos porque sabe que son beneficiosos para los que los consuman, logrando que se sienta muy gratificada con su trabajo. Lo más difícil es el tener que cubrir con la cantidad D. pedidos que le realizan las instituciones, ayudándose muchas veces con sus dos hijas, las cuales la apoyan incondicionalmente. Este es su primer préstamo en Microfinanzas Prisma. Con el dinero solicitado comprará más quinua para hornear, torteras, moldes, etc para realizar todo tipo D. postres.
texts.en:
Juana is 54 years old, is separated from her partner and lives with her daughters, Irma and Geraldine. She is dedicated to selling products maD. from quinoa, including baked cakes, cookies, etc., but all based on quinoa, an Andean (grain) product with many nutritional benefits. Juana likes to bake these products because she knows that there are benefits for those who eat them, which makes her feel her work is very gratifying. The most difficult thing is to cope with the quantity of orders requested by institutions. Her two daughters help her a lot, supporting it unconditionally. This is her first loan with Prisma Microfinance. With the requested money she will buy more quinoa for baking, cakes, molds, etc. to make all kinds of desserts.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and utensils to make her desserts

loans.name: Enriqueta

texts.es: Enriqueta tiene 40 años, es conviviente, tiene 4 hijos, D. los cuales, viven con elL. 2 D. ellos. DesD. muy joven le ha dedicado mucha entrega a sus chacras, por ello no siente dificultad alguna al tener que ir a trabajar en el campo, se levanta a eso D. las 4.00am para preparar los desayunos y el almuerzo D. sus hijos que tiene que ir al colegio, después D. dar alimento a sus vacas, cerca D. las 11.00am, lleva el almuerzo a su esposo en L. chacra. Para esta familia, L. agricultura es su único ingreso económico, a Enriqueta le agrada cultivar sus tierras y cuidar D. su ganado, que a veces le ocasionan problemas por irse a comer los cultivos D. los vecinos. Este es su 7mo préstamo con Microfinanzas Prisma, ha demostrado ser puntual en sus pagos. Con L. cantidad solicitada va a comprar abono y veneno para fumigar las hojas para que tengan buen follaje, ya que L. papa depenD. D. L. hoja, para un buen fruto.
texts.en:
Enriqueta is 40 years old, married, with 4 children of whom 2 still live at home. Since she was young she has worked on the farm, and she doesn’t find it difficult to work in the field. She gets up at 4:00 AM to prepare breakfast and lunch for her children who go to school, then she feeds her cows. Around 11:00 AM she takes lunch to her husband on the farm. For this family agriculture is its only source of income. Enriqueta enjoys farming her land. This is her 7th loan with Microfinanzas Prisma, and she has been punctual in her payments. With the money she is going to buy fertilizer and pesticiD. to fumigate the leaves so that she gets good foliage, as the potato plant depends on its leaf in order to generate good fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and pesticide for her crops

loans.name: Las Triunfadoras De Pan Llevar Group

texts.en:
The women of the Triunfadoras de Pan Llevar are requesting a loan of 5,300 Nuevo Soles to fund their various endeavours.  The Triunfadoras (or Triumphant Leaders) are a relatively new bank: they are just completing their first year as a group together.  They meet monthly in the Saenz Peña neighborhood of Pucallpa, Peru – a bustling capital in the eastern jungle region of the country.

Many of the women sell products in the Ollada market in the Saenz Peña neighborhood.  They are requesting loans of individual amounts, but they collectively guarantee the repayment of the entire bulk loan.  The Triumphant Leaders bank members will be using the loan to fund a variety of businesses including: sales of plantains, fruits, bottled drinks, beauty products, food, vegetables and popsicles.  Each woman will repay her portion of the bulk loan within the same four month term.

The twelve bank members pictured are: Angela V. I.(s/.500), Giovana Karina G. G. (s/.500), Noemi V. R.(s/.500), Belen G. L. (s/.500), Luz Angelica C. G. (s/.300) , Patricia Tuanama I. (s/.500), Maria Estrella G. G. (s/.500) , Victoria D. D. (s/.300), Gloris M. P.(s/.500), Antonia C. C.(s/.500), Gina Ysabel C. G. (s/.400), and Sulianita G. G. (s/.300).

loans.use: To purchase supplies of plantains, fruits, bottled drinks, beauty products, food, vegetables and popsicles for resale

loans.name: Marcelino

texts.es:
Marcelino tiene un pequeño carro de carga donde transporta material de construcción y todo tipo de cargas  dentro la ciudad de El Alto, la esposa es comerciante de verduras, tiene un hijo de 21 años de edad que está estudiando en la universidad estatal. Vive en su casa propia ubicada en la zona Villa Tunari de la ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito lo destinará para la compra de motor para su movilidad, para seguir trabajando con su carro que le sirve de herramienta de trabajo.
 
Es el segundo crédito con Kiva, el buen comportamiento de pago que demostró con nuestra institución le permite acceder a otro préstamo.
texts.en:
Marcelino has a small pickup truck with which he transports construction materials and other kinds of cargo. Within the city of El Alto, his wife is a vegetable vendor. He has a son of 21, who is studying in the state university. Marcelino lives in his own house located in the region Villa Tunari in the city of El Alto. This laon will be used to buy a motor for his truck, so that he can continue working with it, because it serves him as a tool for working. This is his second loan with Kiva. He has displayed good payment behavior with our institution, and so he may access another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a motor for his pick up truck to transport construction material and cargo.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Composé de sept femmes(dont trois enseignantes), les membres du groupe Benkadi de l’association Lafia sont tous mariés et ont une  moyenne d’âge de 26 ans et  2 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec les sœurs, frères, enfants et époux dans le village de Tinimbougou dans la préfecture de Dioïla région de Koulikoro république du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des relations amicales. Elles font principalement la vente d’habits.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire le besoin de la clientèle, elles ont intégré l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles veulent acheter avec ce prêt, 40 pièces de six pagnes auprès des fournisseurs de Dioïla pour les revendre en détail  au comptant et à crédit dans le village de Tinimbougou à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Ces femmes espèrent avoir avec ce prêt 7 000 FCFA de bénéfice chacune, qu’elles  utiliseront pour l’épanouissement de leur activité.
texts.en:
Composed of seven women (out of which three are teachers), the members of the Benkadi group of the Lafia association are all married and average 26 years of age and 2 children. They live in extended traditional families, with their sisters, brothers, children and husbands, in the village of Tinimbougou in the Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region, in the Republic of Mali. They got acquainted through bonds of friendship, and their businesses mainly consists in selling clothing.

Anxious to better satisfy their customers' needs, they joined Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are seeking their third solidarity loan (group loan). All previous loans were repaid without problems. With this new loan, they intend to buy 40 bundles of six pagnes (colorful African cloth) from furnishers in Dioïla, to retail them for cash or on credit in the village of Tinimbougou, to a clientele comprising men and women. These women hope to turn a monthly profit of XOF 7'000 (ca US$ 14) each, to be used to bolster their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and retail pagnes (colorful African cloth)

loans.name: Nelida

texts.es:
La señora Nelida I. D. S.  es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen D. Guadalupe”, del barrio central, en el distrito D. Pomata, Provincia D. Chucuito, Departamento D. Puno; tiene 64 años D. edad, D. estado civil divorciada, tiene 05 hijos y posee estudios D. primaria completa. 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 12 años, ella posee un negocio D. cafetería y Snack en el local municipal del distrito, su primer préstamo fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, monto que invirtió en la compra materiales e insumos para su negocio. 
Actualmente requiere un nuevo préstamo, por tanto viene solicitando la suma D. S/. 800.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que se comprometa a pagar en 05 cuotas mensuales, con dicho préstamo ella desea implementar mejor su negocio D. cafetería y adquirir mas materiales necesarios (tasas, platos, sillas, etc.) asimismo adquirir insumos necesarios (fruta, bebidas, etc.), a fin D. que en el futuro pueda contar con un negocio completo y con gran demanda. 
Ella esta bastante agradecida a Manuela ramos por el apoyo que viene brindando en bien del desarrollo D. las mujeres.
texts.en:
Nelida I. D. S. is a member of Virgen D. Guadalupe Communal Bank, in the central neighborhood of the district Pomata, province Chucuito, departament Puno, Peru; she is sixty four years old, divorced, the mother of five, and has completed primary school. She has been working with Movimiento Manuela Ramos, a feminist organization, for twelve years. She runs her own café and snack bar in her district area. Her first loan was for S/. 300.00, which she used to buy materials and snacks to sell at her café. Now she is requesting a new loan, this time for S/. 800.00, which she will repay in five monthly installments. She will use the loan to better establish her café, and to purchase more necessary materials (cups and plates, chairs, etc.), and important snacks (fruit, drinks, etc.). This will help her to one day have a very strong business and a huge clientele. She is very grateful to Manuela Ramos for their support and helping women to develop.

Translated from Spanish by Hannah Lily, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To better establish her cafe, and purchase necessary materials: cups and plates, chairs, etc.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria O. is 35 years old and married with three children. Victoria sells motor spare parts and is requesting a loan of 100 000 NGN to purchase more motor spare parts to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase motor spare parts to sell

loans.name: Yesi

texts.es: Yesi de 22 años de edad, vive con su pareja y sus dos hijos en la casa de sus padres. El labrado de la tierra es parte de su vida, y su única fuente de ingresos, actividad que realiza junto a su esposo. Yesi tiene un bebé al que debe cuidar, por lo que se siente muy triste cuando su hijo llora mientras ella realiza sus tareas en la chacra llevándolo en la espalda, y como madre se siente impotente de no poder brindarle comodidad a su pequeño, ya que si Yesi no trabaja en el campo, su esposo solo, no avanza con las labores. Ahora siembran papa en las tierras que les prestó su padre, y sus cosechas le han resultado muy rentables, y de ello se siente muy feliz. Con este tipo de trabajo, sus padres le dieron comodidades, y eso espera alcanzar también para el bienestar de su familia, por eso, primero quiere comprar las chacras de sus padres para contar con su propio terreno de cultivo. Yesi en una mujer callada, pero muy responsable en efectuar sus pagos, este es su 4to préstamo con MFP, y le tiene mucha estima y cariño a la institución por la oportunidad brindada. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de fertilizantes para la chacra de papas que tiene sembrada en terrenos temporales.
texts.en:
Yesi is 22 years old. She lives with her partner and her two children in her parent's house. Working the earth is part of her life, her only source of income, and an activity she carries out with her husband. Yesi has a baby that she must take care of, for whom she feels very sad when her baby cries while she is carrying out her work in the small farm, carrying him on her back. And as a mother she feels very helpless since she can't offer her little one any comfort, since if Yesi does not work in the field, her husband alone does not make progress with the work. Now they are planting potatoes in the land that her father loaned them, and her harvests have been very profitable, and for this she feels very happy. With this type of work, her parents are comfortable, and she hopes to reach this too, for the well-being of her family. For this, first she would like to purchase her parent's small farms to have her own land to cultivate. Yesi is a quiet woman, but she is very responsible in making her payments. This is her 4th loan with MFP, and she holds much esteem and affection to the institution for the opportunity offered. The money that she is requesting is to purchase fertilizer for the small potato farm that she has planted in temporary land.

Translated from Spanish by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul A. is a welder by profession. He also deals in vehicle spare parts such as steering wheel covers, crankshafts, etc. He procures goods from Accra and sells them from a workshop in his community. He works very hard to provide for his family. His wife is also a trader. 
Paul is 42 years old. He is married and has five children: four sons and one daughter. All his children are currently in senior high and  primary schools. He lives with his children and wife in a rented apartment in the busy fishing and commercial town of Mankessim, near Cape Coast, in the Central region of Ghana. 
Paul has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure more car spare parts and working materials such as filler, brake fluid, filters, etc. He is hoping to expand his business and give his children the best education he can afford.

loans.use: To buy vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Maria Lorena

texts.es: Doña Maria tiene 37 años de edad, reside en el barrio Laureles Norte en la capital de Managua, casada y con tres hijos los cuales están estudiando, su esposo tiene una tierras las cuales las trabaja, el negocio de la señora Maria es la venta de comida, desde hace cuatro años con fondos que su esposo dio, con este crédito es el décimo ciclo en Afodenic el cual va invertir en comprar granos básicos, verduras, carnes, frutas, para poder preparar los diferentes platillo a sus clientes y elevar las ventas. Sus planes es poder establecer un buen local en la zona franca para seguir creciendo en las ventas como captar clientes. Sus deseos es poder apoyar a sus hijos para que sean hombres de bien preparados profesionalmente.
texts.en:
Maria is a 37 year old woman and she lives in a neighborhood named Laureles Norte, in Managua, the capital of Nicaragua. She is married and she has three children that are in school. Her husband has property that he works on. Maria's job is selling food. She started the business four years ago with money that her husband gave her. With this loan she will buy grains, fruits, vegetables and meats to prepare delicious meals to sell to her customers. Her future plans are to establish her business in a central location, to grow her business and to attract new clientele. Her dream is to help her children become professionals in life.

(Translated by Jasmine of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grains, fruits, vegetables and meats to prepare delicious meals to sell to her customers

loans.name: John's Group

texts.en:
K. John is happy to be asking for another loan today after, together with his fellow group members, completing the repayment of his previous loan.

John is a hardworking man and a taxi driver on the Kampala- Bugerere highway, taking passengers to and fro. He is happy that the loans have made his taxi work well, enabling him to repair it whenever need arises. He has been able to buy land from it, has bought cows that give him milk and he also has farms for agriculture where he is able to produce food for sale and home consumption.

John needs a new loan to help with paying school fees for his six children and to employ workers to help his wife with the farm work.

loans.use: To pay for manpower on his farm and to pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Kapre

texts.en:
Kapre is thirty-seven years old. She is married and the mother of four children. She has three of them in school and her last born is breastfeeding. She has been a supplier of local and foreign palm oil for seven years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nut fruits. She buys them in bulk and supplies them to food vendors to prepare their meals and she even treks to the villages to purchase the finished goods elsewhere when demand becomes very high.

Kapre wants to use the loan to buy more bags of palm nuts, and gallons to store the oil. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to help her husband provide food for her family and finance her children's education.

loans.use: To buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Shumaila Kosar Muhammad Ashraf Group

texts.en:
Shumaila Kosar baji owns a two-room brick house in a city called Arifwala, Pakistan and has been living in it with her family for the past 20 years. Her husband's name is M. A. and he works in a factory for a monthly wage.

Shumaila baji operates an embroidered clothes business, taking orders from her relatives and neighbors. She completes a dress in 4 days and charges US$ 3 for each dress. She does this work to pay the utility bills. She is applying for a loan to buy material (cloth, colored thread, and beads) for her embroidered clothes business.

She is the group leader for four other women from her locality. Shahida Parveen baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell. Sajida Parveen baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit to sell. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart to carry loads. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, cooking oil, and spices) for her food-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible. Note: Shumaila baji is the lady in a black shawl in this photo.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for preparing embroidered dresses

loans.name: Secundino Antonio

texts.es: El señor Secundino tiene la edad de 60 años, reside en el barrio Memorial Sandino en la capital de Managua, tiene dos hijos  mayores de edad, los cuales los dos están desempleados y ha sido difícil la situación, para la familia. Su negocio es la venta de frutas y verduras esto es para obtener otros ingresos ya que el se desempeña como guarda de seguridad por las noches. Con este crédito quiere comprar materiales de construcción para  levantar las paredes de su cocina y poderla tener aparte y tener mejor comodidad. Da las gracias a la institución por los beneficios alcanzados en la mejora de su vivienda a través de los préstamos.
texts.en:
Mr. Secundino is 60 years old. He lives in the community of “Sandino Memorial” in the capital city of Managua. He has grown children. Two of the children are unemployed and this is a difficult situation for the family. His business is fruit and vegetable sales. He does this as a secondary income. At night he works as a security guard. With this loan he would like to buy construction materials in order to build a wall for his kitchen and separate it from the rest of the house. This would make his home more functional. He gives thanks to the institution that is allowing him to improve his home with this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials to build a kitchen.

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua, a 43-year-old married mother of three sons and two daughters, all still in school, works very hard to support her husband in providing for the family. Residing with her family in a rented apartment in Oda in the Eastern region of Ghana, Akosua trades in gari, cassava, and flour in her community. She procures the gari from the nearby communities at moderate prices. Akosua has been in business for five years now and is requesting a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy gari

loans.name: Dorina

texts.en:
Dorina M. is from the village of Carmen Annex in Ozamiz City, which is in the Phillipines province of Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old and married with 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Dorina prepares and sells food, and she has been doing so for over 5 years, earning approximately 4000 PHP a month.

Dorina joined GDMPC in 2007 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dorina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from GDMPC and is now requesting her 4th GDMPC loan, for 6000 PHP, to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale.

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale.

loans.name: Janett Concepcion

texts.es: Doña Janett D. de 44 años de edad, es una mujer luchadora y esforzada para lograr una estabilidad económica en su vida, desde horas temprana se levanta para ir a trabajar en un kiosco que tiene en un colegio en donde vende variados productos a los jóvenes como: frescos, helados, enchilada, golosinas, gaseosas y otros alimento que prepara para vender día a día. Lleva cuatro años administrando el kiosco y espera seguir ya que las venta son buenas es por eso con este financiamiento aumentara las compras para ofertar sus productos y elevar las ventas. Son ocho ciclos los que lleva en Afodenic ya que ha logrado superarse en su negocio solidó, sus planes es poder terminar de hacer unos remodelaciones a su casa, a si como ampliar el local de las ventas. Da las gracias a la institución por hacer posible su incremento en las ventas.
texts.en:
Janett D. is 44 years old. She is a determined woman and works hard to achieve economic stability in her life. She gets up early to work in a kiosk that she has at a highschool where she sells various products to the students, such as: fruit drinks, ice cream, enchiladas, sweets, soft drinks, and other foods that she makes to sell every day. She has been selling at the kiosk for four years and hopes to continue there because sales are good. With this loan she will increase her stock to offer more products and increase her sales. She has been with Afodenic for eight loan cycles and has been able to achieve having a solid business. Her plans are to finish making a few changes to her house and to expand her place of business. She gives thanks to the institution for making her increased sales possible.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy meat, vegetables, and sweets to increase her sales at her kiosk

loans.name: Freddy Edgar

texts.en:
Freddy is a 40-year-old married father of two children. He has a farm where he grows crops as well as producing milk from his dairy cows. For eighteen years now he has been working on the farm, which is located in the town of Sorata, in the Vinto Province of Cochabamba Department. He has been working in agriculture since he was a child helping on his parents' farm.

Freddy plans on using the loan from CIDRE to buy fertilizer as well as seeds for growing potatoes, corn, and parsley. He begins his work before dawn each morning, because he needs to collect the parsley so it can be taken to be sold at the markets in town. This way, he can sell to customers who come to the market in the morning looking for fresh herbs.

Freddy hopes the loan will help him to increase his earnings so that he can build a better home for his family, as the one they live in now is simple and small. He also hopes to continue taking care of his elderly mother, whose health has been deteriorating. While Freddy never finished high school, he does not believe that has impeded the growth of his business. But more than anything, however, he wants to ensure he has enough money saved to fund the entire education of his two daughters.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita B. is from the village of Santa Cruz. She is 52 years old and married and has six adult children. To make a living, Margarita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $107 a month from these activities.

In 2005, Margarita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid previous loans from PMPC.

Margarita is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her eleventh loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Florinda Fabiao

texts.pt:
Florinda Fabião C. nasceu no distrito da Manhiça, província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, tem 34 anos de idade, casada mãe de 4 filhos de 16,9,6 e 3 anos, os 3 mais velhos vão a escola. Fez somente 6ª classe não continuou devido ao casamento pré maturo. Vive na casa própria com os seus filhos em Boane. O marido trabalha na Republica da Africa do sul como serralheiro, para alem dos filhos não sustenta mais ninguém.

Saiu da Manhica com a sua família para Boane onde desenvolve o seu negócio há mais de 5 anos, vendendo produtos de primeira necessidade. Aprendeu a fazer Esta actividade sozinha. Poupa no sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa (xitique) no valor de 2.000.00mt. O marido tem enviado dinheiro para o sustento da família.

Conheceu a Hluvuku – Adsema, através da sua cunhada, que também é cliente desta instituição e nunca teve outros empréstimos em outros bancos.
Este é o seu 2º empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia, ferro e outros) para dar continuidade com a sua obra, que vem construindo em fases. O crédito passado foi de 5.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.

Compromete se a pagar o crédito adequadamente, para poder aceder a mais empréstimos com objectivo futuro de concluir a sua casa, para oferecer melhores condições de habitação a sua família.
texts.en:
Florinda Fabião C. is from the District of Manhiça in Maputo, southern Mozambique. She is 34, married and the mother of four children ages 16, 9, 6 and 3, the three older ones go to school. She finished 6th grade but had to drop school due to an unexpected pregnancy. She lives in her own house with her children in Boane. Her husband works in South Africa as a locksmith and sends the family some money every month. She has her own business in Boane selling first necessity products, activity that she's been performing for the past 5 years. She learned the business all on her own. Florinda is asking for a U$350 loan, which she'll use to buy construction supllies (cement, sand, iron and others) to finish buildng her house and provide her family with better life conditions.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de material de construcao ( cimento, areia e outros)

loans.name: Mrs. Yen Ek Village Bank Group

texts.en: Seventeen people who live in Prey Chheu Teal village in Takeo made up this village bank loan.  Yen E. has selected the members and they will use their loan for different purposes. She is a silk weaver and her husband is a rice farmer who owns a piece of land to earn a living.  Yen requests a loan to buy raw materials to support her business and to buy fertilizer to boost the rice field.  She hopes to increase their income and improve their family lifestyle. She is 28 years old and the mother of two children. One attends school and the other is pre-school age.

loans.use: Buy raw materials and fertilizers.

loans.name: Hind

texts.en:
Hind is a 42-year-old woman who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon, with her husband and their two children. Hind has been selling shoes since 2003. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her work. This is her second loan and she repaid the previous one in a timely manner.

Hind is special in her work because she offers all type of shoes like high heeled shoes, sport shoes and more. Her customers are people from her region. When she first started her business, she didn’t have enough cash to diversify her merchandise. Hind decided on doing her business because she wanted to supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans on improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her work

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia is 39 years old, married and the mother of six children who are school age.  She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana.  Lydia works hard to support her family.  She prepares and sells food on a table by the road side.  Lydia has been in business for seventeen years and wants a loan to buy more bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: Buy bags of maize.

loans.name: Manen

texts.es:
El señor Manaen I. está muy agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual pudo colocar el vitropiso en toda la casa. 
Está solicitando nuevamente otro crédito y su cooperación ya que desea poner el piso de concreto y la barda en el patio trasero de la casa. Pero en este momento no cuenta con el dinero para comprar el material que necesita para la mejora. 
Planea pagar el crédito con el sueldo que percibe de su trabajo como guardia de seguridad de una compañía de trasportes. Ya que su esposa la señora Martha Marlinez se encargara de los gastos de la familia. 
Desea que sus hijos tengan un lugar mas seguro para vivir.
texts.en:
Manaen I. is very grateful for the help provided by his previous loan which allowed him to install tile flooring in the entire house. He is asking for new funding because he wants to install a concrete floor and rear walls in his back yard. However, at present, he lacks funds to buy the necessary supplies to do so. He plans to repay using his salary from his work as a security guard at a transportation company since his wife, Martha Marlinez, takes covers household expenses. He hopes that his children will have a safer place to live.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To lay concrete flooring in the yard and to build rear walls.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 49 years old and is a widow with two daughters who are in school. She owns rental houses and has one employee who takes care of the houses. She was previously a teacher but she currently earns extra income from farming.

Eunice requested Kes 30,000 through Faulu Kenya so as to renovate her rental houses. Faulu Kenya has also helped her save money.

Eunice hopes to establish her own home in the Rongai area of Nairobi in the future. She describes herself as industrious and humble.

loans.use: To renovate her rental houses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy plates, fabrics and toiletries

loans.name: Gladys Piedad

texts.es:
Gladys B. de 50 años, vive en una zona periurbana en Paraíso de Guayaquil su casa es de cemento y cuenta con todos los servicios básicos, es viuda pero tiene 3 hijos ya mayores de edad.

Gladys empezó vendiendo dulces en la esquina de su casa, poco a poco cuando tuvo ingresos suficientes alquilo un local he implemento la venta CD.

Ahora ella tiene una de las tiendas de venta de CD más grandes de su sector, también vende dulces en su negocio. Trabaja desde las 06h00 hasta las 23h00 todos los días. Una de las complicaciones que ha tenido son las lluvias. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar CD y dulces para su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener bien construida su casa y tener otro negocio de venta de CD.
texts.en:
Gladys B., 50, lives in a periurban area of Paraíso de Guayaquil; her house is concrete and has all the basic services. She is a widow and has three adult children. Gladys started selling candies on her corner and gradually earned enough income to rent a space and sell CDs. Now, she has one of the largest CD stores in her area; she also sells candies in her store. She is open for business from 6am until 11pm every day. One of the complications she's had are the rains. She will use the loan to buy CDs and candies for her business. In the future, she would like to have her house well built and have an additional store selling CDs.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For candies and CDs.

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vicente K. is from the village of Tambagan, Medina Misamis Oriental. He is 38 years old. Vicente is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Vicente owns & operates a transport services business for local community members. Vicente has been a driver of a multi-cab for over 5 years and earns approximately 200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Vicente joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Vicente is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Vicente from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand transport services provided.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa C. is from the village of Damayuhan, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old. Rosa is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Rosa owns a sari-sari (variety) retail shop which sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Rosa has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rosa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Rosa is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Rosa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: 16.02.06. Group

texts.en:
Phố N. Thị (10) is a 61-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Phố is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 06. Đông Hải (16.02.06).

Phố is married and has one adult-aged child. To making a living, Phố owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Phố has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, Phố joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Phố has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3079800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. She is now requesting a new loan of 4248000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and then sell. The loan will be the 8th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Phố plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1. N. Thị Phượng (5) is a 50-year-old female who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising crops.

2. B. Thị Thấu (17) is a 52-year-old female who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

3. N. Thị Tú (117) is a 40-year-old female who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising crops.

4. N. Thị Vẹn (44) is a 53-year-old female who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising crops.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Phố N. Thị (10) là 61 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Phố là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 06. Đông Hải (16.02.06). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi heo để bán. Phố thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 15 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Phố kiếm được khoảng 3000000 VND. Vào 2004, Phố đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Phố đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua con giống. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4,248,000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 8th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. N. Thị Phượng (5) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4248000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực. 2. B. Thị Thấu (17) là 52 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4248000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 3. N. Thị Tú (117) là 40 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4248000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực. 4. N. Thị Vẹn (44) là 53 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4248000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là trồng cây lương thực. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and then sell

loans.name: Balemadjourou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Balemadjourou de l’association Lolo est composé de 4 femmes mariées à Kimparana, préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Les membres du groupe Balemadjourou  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles.  Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et ont en moyenne 45 ans et au moins 9 enfants. 
Elles exercent presque la même activité à savoir l’achat et la vente de diverses marchandises (tissus, bijoux, encens, sucre et thé). 
Les femmes du groupe ont intégré le programme  crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis 5 ans et sont à leur  8ème  prêt solidaire. 
Quant à l’utilisation du prêt,  Koroba Traoré compte acheter, 40kg de gueni, 12kg de magnokisseni, 2kg de djekalani et 16 bouteilles de parfums de tous genres. 
Koroba mélange d’abord le gueni avec le parfum eau de Cologne et le dépose pendant une semaine. La semaine suivante elle ajoute tous les parfums et le djekalani pour ensuite les mettre dans des bouteilles qui seront vendues entre  5 000 et 10 000 FCFA à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Koroba compte réaliser un bénéfice de 31000 FCFA par mois et les autres membres espèrent réaliser un bénéfice de 29500FCFA, qui va leurs permettre de rembourser le prêt et de réinvestir dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
The group Balemadjourou of the association Lolo is composed of four married women in Kimparana, Prefecture of San, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the group live in large traditional families, and they know one another through community ties, average 45 years of age, and have at least nine children. They operate nearly the same business, namely buying and selling a variety of merchandise (cloth, jewelry, incense, sugar, and tea). The group members joined the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago and are now on their eighth solidarity loan. As for the use of the loan, Koroba Traoré intends to buy 40 kg of gueni, 12 kg of magnokisseni , 2 kg of djekalani , and 16 bottles of perfumes of all types. Koroba first of all mixes the gueni with eau de ologne and lets it sit for a week. In the following week, she adds all the perfume and the djekalani and then bottles them. They will be sold for 5,000 to 10,000 francs CFA to a customer base composed essentially of women. Koroba plans on making a profit of 31,000 francs per month. And the other members hope to make a profit of 29,500 francs. The profits will enable them to repay the loan and to reinvest in enterprise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying ingredients for making incense

loans.name: Nieves

texts.en: Nieves D. is from the village of Magalalag, Enrile, Cagayan. She is 53 years old, is widowed, and has six school-aged children. Nieves owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP whenever she sells a raised animal. In 2005, Nieves joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Nieves is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her fifth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Odo Nyame Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Hannah describes herself as an intelligent woman. She is 54 years old and is the leader of the “Odo Nyame” (translated as "God of love") borrower group. Hannah is a petty trader who has been selling foodstuffs like yams, maize and coconuts for the past 20 years. She is excited to be taking out this loan, which she will use to purchase yams, bags of maize, and baskets of coconuts in bulk. She dreams of being able to supply yams and maize to restaurant operators. She is married to a cobbler and together they have four children from age 22-42 years. Hannah also hopes to adequately support her last born who is currently pursuing nursing education.

The other members are also engaged in trades such as food selling or selling jewelry and slippers. Hannah says her group members are co-operative.

loans.use: To purchase yams, maize, and coconuts in bulk

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en:
Maricar M. is a 46-year-old married woman from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. Maricar and her husband have 3 school-age children. To earn a living, Maricar owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. More specifically, her primary source of income is derived from selling fish in her local community. Maricar has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Maricar joined HSPFI to gain much-needed access to financial services. In turn, she was able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her standard of living. Maricar has already successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to expand her business. Maricar is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 11,000 PHP ($250), which will be used to purchase more fish to re-sell for profits. Notably, this loan would be the third loan taken out by Maricar from HSPFI. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and it mission is to reach out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To further expand her business by purchasing additional fish

loans.name: Rizza

texts.en:
Rizza L. is from the village of Oro Vista Village, Upper Carmen, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 33 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Rizza owns and operates a business buying and selling different kind of fruits in the local community. Rizza has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Rizza joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fruits to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fruits to sell

location.town: Upper Carmen, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Beatriz Yolanda

texts.es: Beatriz Yolanda L. C. de 41 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Aguilares, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador, en donde se dedica a la venta de jeans para hombres y mujeres, ropa para niños, sandalias, y así mismo cuenta con una pequeña tienda de productos perecederos. Ella vive junto a su esposo quien trabaja como comerciante y así mismo junto a sus dos hijos menores de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar día con día. Beatriz es una persona muy trabajadora, quien desea poder contar con todo lo necesario para ver feliz a su familia, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa de forma ambulante por diferentes colonias de Aguilares, así mismo atiende su pequeña tienda, al mismo tiempo que se dedica a sus hijos. Beatriz solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda invertir más en la tienda, comprando todo lo necesario para convertirla en un negocio bastante fuerte en el cual pueda realizar una mayor cantidad de ventas y así mismo competir con los otros negocios que están a su alrededor, de esta mismo forma ella desea poder comprar mayor cantidad de ropa, ya que este es uno de los negocio de los cuales obtiene mayores ganancias, las cuales son muy necesarias en su hogar.
texts.en:
Beatriz Yolanda L. C., age 41, lives in the Aguilares municipality, located in the department of San Salvador, where she sells jeans for women and men, children's clothing, and sandals. She also has a small perishables store. She lives with her husband who works as a merchant, and their two young children, who go to school every day. Beatriz is a very hard-working person, who wants to be able to have everything necessary to see her family happy. She sells clothing traveling to different districts in Aguilares, and also tends to her own store. At the same time, she takes care of her children. Beatriz is requesting a loan with which to invest more in her store, buying all the necessary items to make it a very strong business where she can make more sales and also compete with the other businesses around. She also wants to buy a greater quantity of clothing, since this is the business which makes her the most money, which is very needed at home.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: the purchase of clothing to sell.

loans.name: Makhbuba

texts.en: Makhbuba R. is a hard working mother. She works as a teacher in a local school, but earns a very low salary. Hard life conditions pushed her to start her own business in 2007. She started breeding cattle and selling it to the local butchers. She has become an experienced farmer and has had successful business growth. This business is the main source of income for her family. Her monthly income is about 250-300 AZN. She works very hard to support her three children. She is requesting a loan of 1,000 AZN.

loans.use: To purchase three calves

loans.name: Ma. Lina

texts.en:
Ma. Lina T. is a married woman who lives in Prk. 6, Brgy. Cabanbanan, Himamaylan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:   Food Vending (bananaque),  a general store and e-loading. Her husband, Francisco T., who is 46 years old, works as an electrician to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 5 and 16 years old. Ma. Lina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Lina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 21,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 6,000 PHP, raising the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing 19,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase more stock for the general store and bananaque (fried banana on a stick) so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Ma. Lina T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her general store

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita T. is from the village of Lobao, Extension, Iligan City. She is 60 years old. Florita is widowed and has 1 child. To make a living, Florita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Florita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Florita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Florita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Lobao, Extension, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Geneviève

texts.fr: D. Geneviève est née le 14 Mai 1977 à Athiémé et est mariée à AMEGNIKOU Daniel, un chauffeur. Le couple a cinq enfants à charge, dont quatre représentent leurs propres enfants. Il y a environs neuf ans que la famille s'est installée à Hêdomey, dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi. Geneviève vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les charges de la famille. Geneviève n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses charges, Geneviève prépare de la nourriture (haricot accompagné de farine de manioc) qu'elle vend à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Geneviève vend de liqueur. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Adja au Mono, que Geneviève s'approvisionne. Geneviève exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans et a déjà obtenu deux prêts qu'elle a bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus importante de sa clientèle, Geneviève désire augmenter son stock de produits et agrandir son activité ; raison pour laquelle Geneviève sollicite un troisième crédit. Geneviève désire plus tard vendre également des sacs de haricot.
texts.en:
Genevieve D. was born May 14, 1977 in Athiémé. She is married to Daniel AMEGNIKOU, a driver. The couple has five dependent children, four of which are their own children. About nine years ago, the family moved to Hêdomey in the town of Abomey Calavi. Genevieve helps her husband to provide for the family. Genevieve did not attend school. To meet the family’s expenses, she prepares dishes (beans with cassava flour) that she sells from her home. As a sideline, Genevieve also sells liquor. She gets her stocks in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and also in Adja, located in Mono. Genevieve has been in this business for five years and has already obtained two loans, which were fully repaid. With customer demand increasing steadily, Genevieve wishes to stock up on supplies and expand her business. This is why she is seeking a third loan. In the future, she would also like to sell bags of beans.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 6 bags of beans, 3 sacks of cassava flour and 5 cans of liquor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase yuca and corn

loans.name: Noor Elahi's Group

texts.en:
Noor elahi lives in a small city of Pakistan called Depalpur. She owns a single-room house in the housing colony named Zia-ud-din and has been living there with her family for over 19 years.
  
She is a 36-year-old lady married to N. A.. She has five sons. Her eldest son is in the army while the remaining four sons are getting their education from a local school. 

Her husband is a driver by profession and drives a rickshaw on local streets. He provides transport services to his passengers and generates income for the family. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband. With the loan, her husband will repair his rickshaw because its engine is creating a problem and needs immediate repairing, otherwise it will seize. With a fully repaired rickshaw, he will be able to provide better transport services to his passengers and also work for longer hours.  

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself as a very responsible client who always paid her installments on time and attended every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who is holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Noor elahi.

loans.use: To repair a rickshaw for a driving business

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe DJIGUISSEME sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs , co-épouses, enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans le quartier Massabla-coura de la ville de BOUGOUNI, (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Ces  femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce, de parenté et de voisinage. 
Afin de satisfaire leurs clientèles en nette croissance, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe et tous les cinq prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt ROKIA K., compte acheter, 3 tonnes de céréales (mil, fonio, arachides, niébé etc) auprès des producteurs des villages environnants. Elle effectue sa vente en détail et en gros, au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, dans le marché de Bougouni, aux consommateurs et revendeurs. 
Avec ce prêt ROKIA espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 85.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisé dans les activités et l’autre partie dans les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The women of Djiguisseme Group are all married. On average, they are 41 years old and have five children.  They live in large traditional families with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children and husbands. They live in the neighborhood of Massabla-Coura of the city of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They have known each other through business, family and neighborhood ties.

In order to satisfy their markedly increasing clientele, they decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is their sixth group loan, after having properly repaid all their previous loans. Rokia Konaté will use her new loan to buy 3 tons of cereals (millet, fonio, groundnuts, cowpeas, etc.) from farmers in nearby villages. She sells her cereals retail and wholesale, for cash and credit, at her home and at the market in Bougouni to consumers and retailers.

Thanks to this loan, Rokia expects to make a monthly profit of 85,000 CFA francs. She will invest it partly in her business and spend it partly on family expenses.

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Cirilina

texts.en:
Cirilina L., who is 50 years old, is a fish vendor from San Francisco, Agusan del Sur. She has four children. She wants to expand her business so that she can send all her children to school. Cirilina also helps her husband maintain their rice farm. She helps plant and harvest their rice crops for sale.

She thinks that funding from CEVI will help her grow her business more. She will use the money from CEVI to buy more fish to resell and additional fertilizers for the farm. In that way, she will be able to earn more and provide the basic needs in their home. 

The income that she will generate from selling fish will also be utilized in paying the school fees and buying home supplies.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell and fertilizers for rice crop

loans.name: Kankalay Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the Kankalay group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Waterloo, a small town in northern Sierra Leone.
