В 1999 году она вышла замуж за  Айбека, работавшего охранником на спиртзаводе, и в  этом же году родила сына.  В 2000 году  Гульнара со своей семьей переехала в село Полтавка, где муж нашел работу,  и в 2009 году у них родилась  младшая дочь. В поисках дополнительного источника доходов для своей семьи, в 2010 году Гульнара начала заниматься разведением скота, и в качестве старта она купила корову с целью получения прибыли от продажи молока и сметаны.  В целях расширения хозяйства, Гульнара обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 80,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дойных коров и кормов. 
В будущем, Гульнара мечтает построить большой дом для своей семьи.
texts.en: Gulnara was born in the Sokuluk village of the Chuy region,  She moved to the city of Kara-Balta after finishing school and was accepted to the Karabalta Medical College in 1995 with a major of a nurse-midwife.  Gulnara finished college with a red diploma (degree with distinction) in 1998 and found work as a nurse in a maternity hospital.  She married Aybek, who worked as a security guard at a distillery, in 1999 and gave birth to a son that same year.  In 2000, Gulnara and her family moved to the Poltavka village, where her husband found a job, and in 2009, they had their youngest daughter.  In search of an additional source of income for her family, Gulnara started breeding livestock in 2010 and bought a cow as a start and with a goal of making a profit from sales of milk and sour-cream.  Gulnara requested a loan in the sum of 80,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to buy dairy cows and fodder in order to expand her business.  In the future, Gulnara dreams of building a big house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase dairy cows and fodder

loans.name: Nver

texts.en:
Nver was born in 1961. He is married and has two sons. One of his sons is a student, and the older one is studying at a branch of Yerevan State University. Nver’s wife works in village administration as a librarian.

Nver is a specialist in agronomy, and he has been working in his specialization since 1985. At the same time, Nver is engaged in farming. On his farm he has cows and pigs, and he grows wheat, corn, and potatoes. However, his primary activity is grape-growing. Nver sells grapes to a wine factory.

Thanks to his occupations, Nver provides for his family and pays for his elder son’s education.

Nver is asking for a 500,000 AMD loan to buy potato seedlings, as well as rope and ties for his vineyard. This is Nver’s second loan from Nor Horizon.

Nver returns home from his wage work late in the evening, and Nor Horizon’s loan officer had to take his photo in the dark.

loans.use: to buy potato seedlings, as well as rope and ties for his vineyard.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is 40 years-old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has three children with one of them currently in school. For the past four years, Godfrey has been working hard to manage his grocery store, which sells posho, beans, flour and other kinds of food. 

To help expand his business, Godfrey has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more maize and flour to resell, and will help Godfrey to generate greater profits and stock more rice for the Christmas season. Godfrey hopes that in the future he will be able to finish up his four-roomed house and shift to working from there. 

Godfrey is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Godfrey who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more maize and flour to resell.

loans.name: Raul

texts.en:
Raul is 48 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with 3 children. 
Raul has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. He has had this business for 5 years. He requested a loan for PHP 11,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages .
Raul has been a member of HSPFI since 2007. In the future, Raul hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Jose Virgilio

texts.es: El señor José a sus 29 años de edad es padre de cuatro hijos de 13, 9, 8 y 6 años de edad, por los cuales trabaja día a día en un local donde presta servicios de computadores, Internet y video juegos desde las 9:00 a.m. hasta las 8:00 p.m, con el ánimo de brindarles una buena calidad de vida y educación. El señor José necesita de la compra de dos computadores y un video juego con los cuales pueda mejorar el servicio prestado y sus ventas, lo que le permita apoyar económicamente a su familia puesto que su esposa se encuentra sin trabajo. El sueño del señor José es ver crecer a sus hijos y poder generar empleos directos en su comunidad.
texts.en: José is 29 years old and the father of four children, ages 13, 9, 8 and 6. It is for their sake that he works day in and day out, at a shop that offers computer service, Internet, and video games from 9:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. His purpose is to offer his children a good quality of life and an education. José needs to purchase two computers and a video game so that he can improve his sales and the service he offers. This will allow him to support his family economically, since his wife is without a job. José's dream is to see his children grow up and to be able to generate jobs in his community.

loans.use: to buy two computers and a video game

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
Teodora is 53 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with eight children. Teodora has a shop that sells fish such as sardines, milk fish and trout. Her husband fishes, using the fishing boat. She has had this business for two years. 

Teodora requested a loan of PHP 11,000 to buy fish to sell. Teodora has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Teodora hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Sorn's Group

texts.en:
A 48-year-old widowed of one child, Sorn resides in a rural village of the Battambang province’s Moung Russey district, Cambodia. To support her living, she has been farming rice and working for others for a fee. She can earn about KHR30,000 per day from the current business and can save about KHR16,000 each day for the future needs.  
This is the fourth loan for Sorn with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Now she is leading her group to seek for a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. She hopes to increase her family’s business and gain more income to build on some savings to increase her family’s business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland

loans.name: Angela

texts.en: Angela is a young mother of a baby girl and she is 26 years of age. She is a primary school teacher who is not satisfied with the meager monthly salary paid by the government of Kenya. She has been trying to fight this for the last three years, currently she has built two rental rooms at Kitengera and they are rented. The group chose her to be their secretary because of being educated and very hard working. In a bid to increase her income, she would like to rear steers because there is ready market today.

loans.use: Angela would like to buy 7 steers for her new business.

loans.name: Aslan

texts.en: Aslan M. has kept bees for honey production for the past six years. He currently lives in Ulguc village in the Agsu region with his wife and three children. With this loan he wants to buy more bees for his honey production.

loans.use: to purchase more bees

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea T. is a 57 year old widow who lives in Phnom Penh with her 1 child and two grandchildren.  She sells furniture and makes about $7/day.  Her child works for a small private company and contributes to the household income.  Chea T. will use this loan to buy furniture products to sell in her store. In the future she plans on continuing with her business until she has enough money to build a larger home where she can also have her shop.

loans.use: To buy furniture products for reselling

loans.name: Maria Dolores

texts.es:
Maria Dolores is a very entrepreneurial and responsible woman. She is a widow and has four children. Her husband passed away eight years ago. Therefore, she had the need to start her own business in order to have enough income to maintain her children and give them the time and attention they needed. She therefore started making food and offering it to nearby offices. Fortunately, demand for her products started to increase and now she has a small food stand.

In order to provide a better service and continue growing like she has so far, Maria Dolores is requesting a US$475 credit, which she will use to purchase chairs and tables to better her business' appearance and increment the number of clients. She promises to repay this quantity in five months. With your loan, Maria can make great things. Be part of her achievements! She sincerely thanks your support.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Maria Dolores es una mujer emprendedora y responsable, ella es viuda y tiene cuatro hijos, hace ocho años que falleció su esposo ella tuvo la necesidad de iniciar su propio negocio para poder obtener un ingreso que le permitiera sostener a sus hijos y darles el tiempo y las atenciones que requieren, así es como inició elaborando comidas y ofreciéndola en unas oficinas cercanas, afortunadamente la demanda por sus productos fue incrementándose y ahora tiene un pequeño puesto.

Para poder ofrecer un mejor servicio y continuar creciendo como hasta ahora Maria Dolores solicita un crédito por $ 475 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mesas y sillas para mejorar la apariencia de su negocio e incrementar sus clientes, ella promete devolver esta cantidad en 5 meses. Con tu ayuda Maria puede hacer grandes cosas, se parte de sus logros, ella agradece sinceramente tu apoyo.

loans.use: Food Stand Remodeling

loans.name: Blanca

texts.es:
Blanca C. H. is 52 years old and she belongs to the “Santa Barbara” Communal Bank. She lives in the Calleria District. She is separated from her husband and has 6 children. She currently sells medicinal plants from the area, such as rue, basil, and aloe. After Blanca separated from her husband, she found herself in a difficult economic situation. When she saw that it is custom in the region to use plants for medicines and also for some rituals, she decided to get into this business, but she didn’t have enough capital. The Movimiento Manuela Ramos gave her the opportunity to invest in this. It was four years ago that she began with a small amount of capital, S/. 300.00 (approximately $94.00). Her current request is for approx S/. 2,000.00 ($625.00).

She will use the money to buy more medicinal plants at whole-sale price. With this amount she could buy 6 bunches of rue, 5 bunches of rosemary, 2 of aloe, and 2 of Holy Wood, 6 of charamasho, and a dozen bottles of scented water.

Blanca is happy with this opportunity because in this way she will be able to get ahead and provide for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Blanca C. H., tiene 52 años de edad, pertenece al Banco Comunal "Santa Barbara", vive en el A. H. Los Rosales MZ Z Lt 15, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Es una mujer separada con 6 hijos, actualmente vende plantas medicinales de la Región como Ruda, albaca y sábila. Blanca después de su separación con su esposo se encontró en una situación difícil en lo económico, fue cuando vio que las costumbres del uso de plantas así como algunos rituales es lo cotidiano en la Región, entonces se propuso poner este negocio pero no tenia el capital, sin embargo Manuela Ramos le dio la oportunidad de invertir en este rubro y hace 4 años empezó con un pequeño capital de S/. 300 (US$ 94.00 aprox.), siendo su préstamo actual de S/. 2,000 (US$ 632.00 aprox.). Este préstamo lo requiere para comprar mas plantas medicinales por atados, es decir, más cantidad a un costo menor, con esto podrá comprar 6 atados de Ruda, 5 atados de Romero, 2 atados de sabila, 2 docenas de Palo Santo, 6 atados de Charamasho y 1 docena de agua florida. Blanca esta contenta con esta oportunidad ya que de esta manera podrá salir adelante junto a sus hijos.

loans.use: To buy medicinal plants at whole-sale prices.

loans.name: Amie

texts.en:
Amie is 43 years old and married with 4 adopted children.  She started her business by selling cookies.  With her first loan, she added palm oil and spices to her business. Her subsequent loans enabled her to diversify her business. She now sells clothes, plastic sandals and saucepans, in addition to selling her palm oil and spices.  Although Amie has no biological children, she feels happy that she can adopt her brother's and sister's children, and is proud to provide them with an education.  
<Pp>
A powerful woman, Amie involves her husband in the business and he normally purchases the supplies.  Amie would like to increase her stock, specifically the palm oil and spices so she can export them to the Republic of Guinea.  She is therefore requesting a loan of $675. With the profit from her business, she purchased land and she is in the process of building a family house.

loans.use: Expansion of her business by purchasing additional palm oil and spices for exporting.

loans.name: Minaver

texts.en: Minaver S. is 27-year-old single woman who lives in the southern region Imishli with her parents. She has six years of experience in animal breeding. Minaver covers all the family's needs. Her parents are very old and ill people. Half of the money she earns she spends on medicine and the rest for food. Minaver's father got ill when she was fifteen and she left school as soon as she finished ninth grade. She didn’t get a university degree and now she is unemployed. Keeping cattle is the only  financial source in her family. This is a very hard time for her and her family. She has applied for 800 USD with repayment term of 15 months. With this amount she is going to purchase one milking cow. Minaver is certain that a milking cow will bring her good income; she would be able to sell milk and yoghurt to the local bazaar traders and to the neighbors.  Owning the cow would allow her family to always have cheese, butter and yoghurt.

loans.use: To purchase one milking cow

loans.name: Rehana

texts.en: “I live in the small town of Vehari which lies near the cotton belt of Pakistan. My husband and I, along with our four children, live in a two-room house. My husband has a fruit cart and wants to purchase seasonal fruits in bulk for re-sale in our town. With a loan, he will be able to sell bananas, apples, grapes, and pomegranates. Our business is now pretty successful since last year we took out a loan and were able to reinvest the profits in our business and also send our children to school. This year we hope to do the same. I also help my husband by stitching clothes for women and children in our neighbourhood.”

loans.use: Purchase and re-sell fruits

loans.name: Tania

texts.es:
Mrs. Tania has been selling food at night for a long time, typical regional dishes such as “juanes”, fish wrapped in husk or leaves, among others. She is a 33 year-old single mother with two beautiful children named Anthony and Naysha who are students and her inspiration to make progress. Her intention is to expand her business and buy a counter in order to sell cold beverages (beer and soft drinks) and the loan will be used for that purpose. With your support make this hardworking mother’s dream come true for the well-being of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Tania vende comida por la noches desde hace mucho tiempo, se dedica a la venta de platos típicos de la región (juanes, pescado envuelto en hoja entre otros), tiene 33 años y es madre soltera sus dos hermosos hijos de nombres Anthony y Naysha están estudiando y son sus aspiraciones de progreso. Ella tiene un propósito, ampliar su negocio y comprar un exhibidor para vender bebidas heladas(cervezas y gaseosas), pero para este objetivo le urge un préstamo. Con tu apoyo has posible el sueño de esta madre que trabaja incansablemente por el bienestar de los suyos.

loans.use: Expand business of food sales.

loans.name: Alma Bedelia

texts.es:
I have a business that sells used and new clothing. I set up shop outside my home, which allows me to also take care of my family. My store needs new merchandise and a wider variety of items; I would also like to sell shoes. I ask for a loan of $700 USD to purchase new merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo un negocio de venta de ropa usada y nueva. El negocio lo tengo fuera de mi casa y así atiendo a mi familia. En el negocio me esta haciendo falta mas mercancía nueva y variedad de artículos, también me gustaría vender calzado. Solicito un préstamo de $700.00 Dlls para la compra de mercancía nueva.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Samrith

texts.en:
Mrs. Samrith S., 42, works as a weaver and also owns a plot of land growing rice. On average, she earns around $3 a day. Her husband works as a construction worker building houses, making about $5 a day. They have 2 children. One child works in a garment factory and the other stays at home.
She would like to loan from Kiva to purchase good rice seed and fertilizers to put on her farm and the leftover is to be used to buy a motorbike for use as  transportation.

loans.use: to purchase  good rice seed and fertilizers and a motorbike.

loans.name: Kan

texts.en:
Kan Y. is a 22 year-old housewife who lives in Siem Reap, Cambodia. Her husband, Veng Von, is 23 and has worked as a construction worker since 2003. He earns approximately $5 per day. The couple is pictured above with their daughter.

Kan Y. would like to take out a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband. With the motorbike, her husband would be able to commute to work more easily.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work with

loans.name: Goma

texts.en:
Goma K. is married and has two children -- a daughter who is in the eighth grade and a son in the seventh. Her husband, Mr. Manohari, works at a factory in a nearby industrial area.

Goma K. owns one cow and and makes a living selling milk in her area. In Nepal pure, fresh cow’s milk is highly valued as a beverage and for its contribution to health. She carries her milk around with her in containers and sells it door to door every morning and every evening.

Goma K. lives in a growing neighborhood in which demand for milk is constantly increasing. To help meet this demand, she would like to buy another cow to increase her production. She plans to purchase a jersey cow, which produces more milk than most cows, and has applied for a $300 loan to fund the purchase.

loans.use: To buy a second cow to produce milk to sell.

loans.name: Chhea

texts.en: Chhea S. L. is a widow who lives in Sa Ang where she sells porridge and rice. She typically makes $4 each day in the market and is also supported by her daughter who works in the garment factory. Inflation has been very high in Cambodia over the past year and it has affected food prices and the costs of other basic necessities. Many Cambodians are struggling to pay these higher prices and have turned to microloans to help them improve their circumstances. Chhea S. L. has asked for a loan of $400 to invest in her rice business. The price of rice has risen rapidly, and she sees this investment as a good way to increase her daily income. She would also like to use some of the money to purchase some land to fill the business site during the rainy season. During the rainy season there are many floods, and she understands that she needs to be very careful with her rice crop.

loans.use: Invest in rice business; Purchase land to fill business site

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov O. is a farmer in Trapaing Pour Village in Kampong Speu Province. She is a 53-year-old widow without any children. Being the only earner, she lives in poor conditions. Mrs. Pov O. wants to improve her standard of living so  she decided to ask for a loan to build a new house to replace the old one.

loans.use: Build a new house to replace the old one.

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida K. has been selling used clothing and soft drinks at Siwdo since 2007. Vida has received a primary education. She is married and has 3 children; her husband is an accounts clerk. She is responsible for paying for her children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more used clothing and soft drinks for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to renovate her store.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more used clothing and soft drinks for sale.

loans.name: Neam

texts.en: Neam S., 29, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. Since 2005, she has been working as farmer growing rice to earn a profit US$2.5 each day. Her husband, Hoeung Sam, 37, is a miller. He has a grinding machine and is able to make US$3.5 each day. Three of their children are students and the other one is too young to attend school. Neam told a loan officer that on average her family needs to spend around US$60 on food, US$30 on utilities, and US$50 on their children's education. Neam is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase more rice for her husband to grind and sell. (Hoeung is pictured at his home.)

loans.use: To purchase more rice for her husband to grind and sell.

loans.name: Kuya

texts.fr:
Mariée à un cultivateur, Mme Kuya D. est née en 1958 au Ghana. N’ayant reçu aucune formation, elle s’est également engagée dans l’agriculture à travers la culture du mais qu’elle produit et revend sur le marché. Cette activité lui permet de soutenir son mari financièrement. 
Pour augmenter son rendement, elle sollicite un financement pour l’achat d’intrants notamment les engrais et les semences.
texts.en:
Ms. Kuya D. was born in Ghana in 1958 and is married to a grower. Not having received any training at all, she has dedicated herself as well to agriculture through the growing of corn, which she produces and then sells on the market. This work enables her to support her husband financially. To increase her yield, she is requesting financing to buy supplies, notaly manure and seeds.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy agricultural supplies

loans.name: Raquel

texts.es: Raquel de 38 años de edad, es madre de 3 hijos que estudian, vive junto a su conviviente que la apoya en sus objetivos. Ella se dedica a la venta de ropa al por menor, los lleva a vender por los distintos lugares de su zona, esta labor la viene realizando desde hace 3 años. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que conoce muchos lugares e intercambia ideas con sus clientes.  Le es rentable, ya que cuenta con una clientela selecta. Y le va muy bien. Este es su cuarto préstamo, y ha pagado siempre de manera puntual. Ahora desea comprar más prendas en distintos modelos para niños y adultos, posteriormente alquilar un local para poner su tienda de ropa.
texts.en:
Raquel is 38 years old, the mother of 3 school age children, and lives with a partner that supports her in her objectives. For 3 years she has sold clothing, taking them to different places in her area. What she likes about her work is visiting different places and exchanging ideas with her clients. The business is profitable because it has a select clientele. She is doing very well. This is the 4th loan and she has always paid on time. Now she wants to buy more clothing in different styles for adults and children and rent a place to put her clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Jeanette Chase, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy different styles of children's clothes.

loans.name: Kossi

texts.en:
Kossi H. is a 36-year-old married father. In the local language, Ewe, his first name indicates that he was born on Sunday. Kossi lives in the village of Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the Togolese capital. To provide for his family, Kossi sells ‘sandelettes,’or flip-flops, in a small boutique located in the central market in Wome. These comfortable and inexpensive shoes are very popular among Togolese in this region and are always in demand.

Kossi hopes to use the money from this loan from FECECAV to make his shop look more professional through the creation of a display for his flip-flops. He hopes to attract more customers and compete with other vendors. With the profits from his business he will be able to continue to support his children and improve their quality of life.

loans.use: To make his shop look more professional

loans.name: Jenifer Milagros

texts.es:
Jennifer es socia del Bancomunal Perlas de la Sabiduría 
Jennifer tiene 28 años es separada tiene cuatro hijos de 13, 9, 8, y 3 años sus hijos están en la escuela estatal José Maria Arguedas.  
Jennifer ha trabajado en una imprenta, después  trabajo para una fabrica vendiendo puerta por puerta mermelada, también vendiendo  ropa en un puesto en el mercado, siempre trabajando para otros pero desde noviembre del 2008 ella decidió ser  independiente y con la llegada de la navidad ella decidió empezar a vender juguetes, luces navideñas a sus amigas, vecinos  y conocidos gracias a Dios ya tiene realizada varias ventas 
Jennifer solicita un préstamo de 400 soles para la comprar mercadería de juguetes para la campaña navideña 
Jennifer encuentra en  Finca mucha ayuda y orientación para su negocio.
Los sueños que tiene Jennifer son incrementar sus ingresos, y comprar una maquina de coser a hacer polos, ha ella le gustaría tener su taller de costura                                                                                                                               
Jennifer ha pasado por situación muy difícil en su vida cuando salio en estado de su cuarta hija  su pareja la abandono, quedando ella emocionalmente 
dañada recibió ayuda de psicólogos y personas que le hablaron de Dios
texts.en:
Jennifer is a partner of the communal bank called Perlas de la Sabiduría. Jennifer is 28 years old, who is separated and has four children who are 13, 9, 8, and 3 years old. Her children are attending the state school José Maria Arguedas. Jennifer worked in a printing shop, later she worked for a factory selling marmalade on the street and she has also worked selling clothes in a stand at the market. She has always worked for others but in November, 2008 she decided to be independent and with the arrival of Christmas, she decided to start selling toys, and Christmas lights to her friends, neighbors and acquaintances. Thanks to God, she has already made several sales. Jennifer is requesting a loan of 400 soles ($150) to buy merchandise like toys for the Christmas season. Jennifer has found in Finca (Kiva's field partner) a lot of help and orientation for her business. Her dream is to increase her income, and to buy a sewing machine to make sweaters. She would like to have her own workshop. Jennifer has gone through a very difficult situation. When she became pregnant of her fourth daughter, her partner left her. She was in a really bad emotional state and had to get help.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Toys for her business

loans.name: Claudia Maria

texts.es:
Claudia es una joven de 27 años de edad, reside en Hialeah, a mucho esfuerzos ha podido terminar su carrera en administración de empresa, 
Trabajando en un colegio público  como docente de secundaria con nueve años de experiencia en las labores, con esto se ayudaba apagar sus estudios. Su esposo es maestro de obra, tiene una niña de 6 meses. Sus metas es pode tener su propia casa ya que están viviendo en la casa de su mama, este es su tercer crédito en Afodenic que lo quiere invertir en la reparación del techo del cuarto donde habita ya que esta bien deteriorado, y desea estar en buenas condiciones para proteger y cuidar a su bebe. Sus objetivos para el futuro es poder cambiar de puesto y mejorar de nivel en lo profesional, como en su vida personal.
texts.en:
Claudia is a young 27-year-old who lives in Hialeah. Through much effort she has been able to finish her studies in business administration. She helped pay for her education by working in a public school as a secondary school teacher, in which she has nine years of experience. Her husband is a construction foreman and she has a 6 month old girl. Her goal is to have her own house as they are currently living in her mother´s house. This is her third loan with Afodenic which she wants to invest in fixing the ceiling of the room she lives in as it is quite deteriorated and she would like it to be in good condition to protect and care for her baby. Her objectives for the future are to be able to change jobs and improve her standing professionally and personally.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials to repair the ceiling of a room.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.es:
La Sra. Elsie V. de 36 años de edad, esta casada con el Sr. Heriberto Zarate de 39 años, ellos tienen un hijo que esta cursando sus estudios primarios. 

Doña Elsie empezó este negocio aproximademente en el año 2.004; con el capital que pudieron juntar del ingreso que tiene el señor, empezaron a comprar uno a uno las máquinas cada ves que podian, hasta que llegaron a comprar las máquinas básicas para poder empezar a trabajar, en la actualidad le provee muebles a dos personas, todo el tiempo.

La Sra. Elsie utilizaría este crédito en comprar más mercaderías, para satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Elsie V. is 36 years old, married to Heriberto Zarate who is 39 years of age, and they have one child who is in primary school. Elsie started her business in the year 2004 approximately. With the capital they were able to gather from her husband’s income, they began to buy machines one by one as they were able. They managed to buy the basic machines necessary to begin working. Currently, she provides furniture to two people at all times. Elsie will use this loan to purchase more merchandise to satisfy her customers’ demands.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase lumber.

loans.name: Améyo

texts.fr: Cette dame réside dans le quartier d’adidogomé, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce d’ignA. et de diverses céréales dans sa boutique qu’elle appelle « Ets Dieu de grace ». Les propriétaires de restaurant viennent acheter chez cette dame de l’igname pour préparer du fufu qui est très apprécié dans la cuisine togolaise. Son stock de marchandises étant épuisé, elle sollicite un crédit chez wages pour l’achat d’ignA. et de céréales, elle est mariée et a un enfant.
texts.en:
This is a lady who resides in the Adidogomé district. Her income-generating work involves commerce in yams and in various grains out of her shop, which she calls « Ets Dieu de grace ». Restaurant owners come to this lady to buy yams for making fufu, which is highly appreciated in Togolese cuisine. Her stock of merchandise being exhausted, she’s requesting a loan from WAGES to buy yams and grain. She is married and has a child.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy yams and grain

loans.name: Josenta Atieno

texts.en:
Josenta Atieno E. is 23-year-old mother of two children aged 6 and 3. A widow, Josenta supports her family and sends the kids to school by selling "mandazi" in the morning and vegetables in the evening. She cooks the mandazyi herself and told us that all it takes is baking flour, sugar, a little salt and some milk to make the dough. Then she fries it.

Josente buys her vegetables from Kibuye market in downtown Kisumu and brings them back to the Nyamasaria slum. She hopes to use the loan to purchase more inventory for her business and the rest for poultry or livestock as extra food security. She is asking for 20,000 KSH and would like Kiva lenders to know that the profit will go to pay for school fees for her children.

loans.use: more inventory for her businesses

loans.name: Armando Alonso

texts.es:
El joven Armando Alonso es trabajador de confianza de una muy reconocida ferretera, como encargado de supervisor de créditos, desde hace un año.
Es una muy responsable y trabajadora que busca día con día emprender nuevos retos; como tal hoy tiene el proyecto de comprar madera para rentarla a arquitectos, motivo por el cual esta tramitando este crédito.
texts.en:
Young Armando Alonso is a trusted worker of a very well known train company. He’s been working as a credit supervisor for a year. He is very responsible and a hard worker who seeks for new challenges every day. Today, his project is to purchase wood to rent to architects, reason why he's requesting for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wood to rent to architects

loans.name: Miriam

texts.es:
Miriam  es socia del Bancomunal Mujeres Emprendedoras.
Miriam es  de Huanuco, casada tiene 65 años, cuatro hijos que son mayores.
Miriam comenzó vendiendo pasamanería  en el mercado, pero falleció su papa y cerro, con los ahorros que tenia decidió poner un negocio de Internet con la ayuda de su hijo, hace un año. Su esposo administra su negocio. 
Miriam necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles, para la compra de teclados, tinta originales e insumos para el Internet.
Desde que esta en Finca aprendió a conocer a las personas, a saber como tratar con ellas, agradece a Finca por los préstamos otorgados puede invertir en su negocio.
El sueño de Miriam, es tener poner otro Internet.
texts.en:
Miriam is a member of Bancomunal Mujeres Emprendedoras (Enterprising Women Communal Bank). Miriam is from Huanuco, is married, is 65 years old, and has four grown children.

Miriam started selling decorative trim (passementerie) in the market, but her father passed away and she closed. With the savings that she had she decided one year ago to open an internet café with the help of her son. Her husband administers the business.

Miriam needs a loan of 1600 PEN to purchase keyboards, printers, and products for the internet.

Since she has been in the program she has learned how to get to know people, how to deal with them, and she is grateful to the program for the loans granted to her that she can invest in her business. Miriam’s dream is to be able to open another internet café.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of keyboards, printers, and products for the interent

loans.name: Jose Oswaldo

texts.es:
El Señor José M. tiene 21 años de edad, casado tiene un hijo de nueve años de edad. Como padre responsable la seguridad y la estabilidad para su hijo es el primer plan en sus proyectos.
Don José M. trabaja como asesor de venta en una empresa del país. Desde hace 1 año se desempeña en ese puesto. Todo el esfuerzo que realiza es para que su familia tenga la mejor y mayor comodidad.
El préstamo que solicita en Afodenic es para seguir construyendo su casa comprando materiales de construcción como: cemento, hierro, bloques, ladrillo, zinc para construir un cuarto mas ampliando un poco su casa y tener una casa digna para su familia.

loans.use: Comprar materiales de construccion para terminar de construir su vivienda

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr: Cette  jeune femme est une femme célibataire, elle travaille dur pour pouvoir subvenir à ses besoins quotidiens elle s’est lancée dans le commerce d’appareil d'ustensiles de cuisine.  Elle s’approvisionne au marché  local du port autonome de Lomé. Son stock étant épuisé elle veut se réapprovisionner et ayant déjà obtenu de WAGES un crédit, elle sollicite son deuxième crédit pour acheter 4 cuisinières de haute qualité, 2 moulinesse, 4 thermousse 2 cartons de plats et 5 lanternes de WAGES.
texts.en:
This young woman is an unmarried. She works hard to be able to support herself day to day. She got started in the commerce of kitchen utensils and equipment. She stocks up at the local market of the Autonomous Port of Lomé. Being out of stock, she wants to resuppy herself. And having had a WAGES loan, she’s requesting her second loan to buy four high-quality cookers, two moulinesse, four thermousse, two boxes of plates, and five lanterns.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy kitchen utensiles

loans.name: Roselyne

texts.en:
Roselyne, or Rose, sells various vegetables in the neighborhood of Nyamasaria, near Kisumu, Kenya.  She has a small kiosk on the main street.  By buying 1,500 shillings worth of vegetables to resell, Rose can make between 250 and 500 shillings each day.  She averages between 10 and 15 customers each day, but the traffic at her small stand can fluctuate quite a bit.  Rose established her stand in 1997, and has never seen food prices rise as fast as they are now.  The added expense of purchasing her stock has pinched her profit margins.  That is on top of the struggles she faced during the post-election violence in Kenya in 2007.  Her small stand was burned and her entire stock of vegetables was destroyed.  However, two months later, she was back at it with a rebuilt business.  

With her loan, Rose would like to buy a bigger selection and a larger quantity of vegetables.  She would also like to start selling basic medicines and nutrients for sick members of her community.  She has two children, ages 14 and 8 months.  She takes her 8-month-old daughter to work with her since she doesn’t have anyone to watch her during the day.

K-MET, the NGO giving the loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional MFI. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya.  For more information about K-MET, please use the following link: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=24

loans.use: To purchase a bigger selection of vegetables

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en: Angelina is twenty nine years old. She is married and has one son who is currently attending primary school. She lives with her husband and child in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town in the western region of Ghana. Angelina is a retail seller of eggs. She sells at the market square in her community. Angelina buys crates of eggs from nearby poultry farms. She also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Angelina has been in business for four years and wants a loan to buy crates of eggs in bulk to expand her business. She hopes to give her child quality education and improve upon her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy crates of eggs for resale

loans.name: Nancy Carmela

texts.es:
La señora Nancy, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa C. de Barco”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Chucuito Sector Barco, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 34 años de edad, de estado civil Soltera, no tiene hijos, tiene estudios de secundaria completa, vive en Chucuito, Sector Barco.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 6 años,  con un préstamo inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual utilizó para la compra de abarrotes. Ahora tiene un criadero de truchas, es el negocio al cual se dedica actualmente..

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 200.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de alimento balanceado para truchas, ella tiene su puesto en el mercado de Puno.

Su deseo es poner una tienda grande para venta de abarrotes y así estabilizarse en un lugar.

A ella le gustan los ahorros y las reuniones.
texts.en:
Señora Nancy is a member of the Santa C. de Barco Community Bank located in the district of Chucuito Sector Barco, Province of Chucuito, Department of Puno. She is 34 years old, unmarried, has no children, and completed her high school studies. She lives in Chuciuto, Sector Barco. She has been working with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for 6 years. With an initial loan for S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, she was able to purchase groceries. Now she runs a trout nursery. She needs a loan for S/. 200.00 Nuevos soles to purchase balanced nutrients for the trout. She has a stall at the Puno market. Her dream is to have a large store to sell groceries and establish herself in one location. She enjoys cost savings and reunions.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Raimondi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase balanced nutrients for trout.

loans.name: Ropolon Group

texts.en:
These people are Hassan S. T. and Fatu C.. They call their group Ropolon, named after the village of the group’s leader.  They are local entrepreneurs in the town of Magburaka, about fifteen miles from Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. This is the fourth time they’ve received a loan through SMT. Previous loans have had meaningful impacts on the lives of these borrowers. They were able to use the proceeds to pay their children’s school fees.  They’re also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans.   They are requesting a loan of Le 2,600,000 to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Hassan S. T. (left) is the leader of the group. He is forty-one years of age. He was born in a village called Ropolon about two miles from Magburaka town.  He is married with four children between the ages of ten and twelve. Hassan has been selling ready-to-wear-clothes for the past ten years now.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Anamarie

texts.en:
Anamarie is a fruit vendor in the village. She is 26 years old and married to Marlon who is working as a tricycle (local three-wheeled vehicle) driver. Her husband is a good provider; he focuses on the needs of their family especially the education of their children. They are blessed with two children: Mark Anthony, 8 years old, and Marian Angela, 6 years old. They are living peacefully at Barangay South Caronsi Peñablanca, Cagayan.

Anamarie is requesting a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP 9,000. She plans to use the loan to buy more fruit that she will sell and hopes that she can develop her business so she can have a fruit stand in the public market. It is really her dream to make her business grow for the future of their children, thus she is praying for the support of KIVA lenders.

She is able to generate PHP 2,000 weekly gross income from her vending and according to her it is not enough, so she is trying her best to cope with the increasing price of commodities. She believes that her dreams of becoming a successful fruit vendor will be achieved through her patience and hard work.

loans.use: to buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Claudia

texts.es:
Claudia es socia del Banco Comunal Llamkasun que significa Trabajemos.
Claudia es casada, tiene 34 años y 4 hijos, Claudia se dedica a la elaboración de panes típicos, actividad que realiza en un horno alquilado, sus ventas son por las tardes en el mercado Santa Clara, además Claudia vende ropa en la feria de las Américas.
Claudia necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de harina.
Los sueños de Claudia son tener una panadería y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Para la compra de harina.

loans.name: Pascual

texts.es:
Pascual se dedica a la cría de ganado vacuno, cuya producción de leche lo comercializa a Pil Andina (Planta Industrializadora de Leche). Su esposa se dedica al cuidado de sus hijos los cuales se encuentran en edad escolar, también colabora en el cuidado del ganado.
Reside en la localidad de Chojñacollo de la Provincia Los Andes ubicado a cinco horas de La Ciudad de la Paz.

El crédito lo destinara en la compra de una vaca lechera y así incrementar la producción de leche para poder tener mejores ingresos.

Es el primer crédito con IMPRO, la evaluación realizada califica para la aprobación del préstamo solicitado por Pascual.
texts.en:
Pascual raises dairy cows and sells the milk he produces to Pil Andina (an industrial milk plant). His wife takes care of their school-aged children and assists him with looking after the cows. He and his family live in the town of Chojñacollo in Los Andes Province, which is located 5 hours away from the city of La Paz.

Pascual’s loan will be used to buy another dairy cow so that he can increase his milk production and improve his earnings. This is his first loan with IMPRO. His evaluation indicated that he was approved for the loan he requested.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase another dairy cow to increase milk production

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina A. is from the village of Taboc Norte. She is 48 years old, married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Lina owns and operates a fruit business venture in the food sector. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of fruits in the local community. Lina has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Lina joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 37-year-old man who lives in Saida in southem Lebanon with his wife and their one child. Ali has been working as a taxi driver since 2000. Ali requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase a new car. This new car will provide him some additionA. revenue because he plans to rent it. This is the fourth cycle and he has always paid on time.

Ali is good at his work because he knows how to treat his clients. They are his friends, neighbors and passers-by. When he first started his business, he didn’t own a car, so he had to rent one. That cost him a lot and didn’t allow him to save money. Before he started working as a taxi driver, he used to work as a school bus driver, but he decided to find independent work and started working as a taxi driver.

loans.use: To purchase a new car.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is a 55-year old rice farmer. She started her business in 2008. With her rice farming, she has been able to provide for her two children. Her eldest child is only 10 years old and she wants her children to be educated. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to get financial help for her business. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 Php, which is just enough to buy fertilizer and pay for the labor necessary to manage her rice field.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pay for labor.

loans.name: Tamarindo Group

texts.es: El grupo “Tamarindo” esta representado por la señora María C. y conformado por 13 miembros que buscan progresar en las distintas actividades que realizan para poder cumplir con sus pagos que realizaran. Entre las actividades que realizan las socias tenemos la venta de pan,  comida, abarrotes, gaseosa y como empleados en diferentes empresas. La competencia con respecto a sus negocios es fuerte, ya que todos tienen que trabajar duro para poder sacar adelante sus negocios y para poder llevar el pan de cada día a sus hogares. El destino del crédito es para la adquisición de materiales, mercadería e insumos para el incremento de sus ingresos y para brindarles a sus familias una mejor calidad de vida.  Algunas personas tienen experiencia en grupos solidarios gracias  a créditos en otras instituciones pero les dan las gracias a la fundación Agrocapital por el apoyo brindado y por confianza en los miembros del grupo y por una nueva oportunidad para seguir creciendo.
texts.en:
The Tamarindo Group is represented by María C. and made up of 13 members who strive for progress in their different activities to meet their payment obligations. Among the activities of the members we have the sale of bread, food, groceries and soft drinks; some of them are employees in various companies. The competition in their activity sectors is strong and so they must work hard to run their businesses and be able to put food every day on the table.

They will use the loan to purchase materials, goods and inputs to increase their earnings and offer a higher quality of life to their families. A few members have already some experience with solidarity groups thanks to loans from other microfinance institutions, but they thank Fundación Agrocapital for their support and trust in the members of their group and for the new opportunity for further growth.

Translated from Spanish by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Yana Yolanda

texts.es:
Yana T. de 44 años de edad, tiene una casa de cemento ubicada en el Fortín de Guayaquil, esta en unión libre con su pareja el le ayuda con los gastos de la familia siendo albañil en urbanizaciones de Guayaquil, tiene 2 hijos uno estudia en una escuela Particular y su otro hijo trabaja. 

Yana comenzó su negocio hace 2 años atrás, con sus ahorros compro pollos para criadero y así ella mismo los mataba y los entregaba a sus clientes. Ahora ella vende pollos listos para cocinar a $ 5.60 según lo que pesen. Trabaja desde las 07h00 hasta las 12h00, una de las mayores complicaciones que ella tiene es la competencia de las tiendas, y la delincuencia.

Con el préstamo Yana quiere comprar más pollos y arreglar el criadero para agrandar el negocio. En el futuro quiere comprar un solar por su sector para tener otro criadero de pollos, y con esto que le ayude a poner un bazar para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Yana T. is 44 years old and has a cement house situated in Fortín de Guayaquil. She is in a common law relationship with her partner who helps her with family expenses, being a mason in residential developments of Guayaquil. She has two children: one studies in a private school, and her other child works. Yana began her business two years ago. With her savings, she bought chickens to raise, and she herself slaughtered them and delivered them to her customers. Now she sells chickens ready to cook for $5.60, according to their weight. She works from 7:00 a.m. until 12 noon. One of her biggest problems is competition from other shops and petty crime. With the loan, Yana wants to buy more chickens and fix up the coop in order to expand her business. In the future, she would like to buy some land in her area in order to have another chicken coop, which would help her to set up a shop for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase chickens and fix up chicken coop.

loans.name: Bahruz

texts.en: Bahruz K. is 28 years old young and a very enthusiastic man. He has owned a plastic door manufacturing company for the last four years. He likes his job very much. That’s why he is very friendly and polite with every single client, He says that to be a successful entrepreneur you have to be excellent at your job. He is busy every single minute and works from early morning until late night. Bahruz applied for 1600 AZN to improve his working conditions and purchase more materials.

loans.use: To improve working conditions and purchase materials

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es:
Lidia tiene 48 años, es casada y tiene cuatro hijos. Lidia se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como por ejemplo preparar desayuno y limpiar la casa. Lidia se dedica a la venta D. churros en la calle en una carretilla. Ya son diez años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Lidia requiere el préstamo para comprar 20 kilos D. harina. (Churros postres que se elabora con harina y en el centro tiene un relleno D. manjar)

Lidia pertenece al banco comunal “las hijas D. Maria” D. la Asociación Arariwa y se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
48-year old Lidia is married and has four children. She gets up very early to do household chores such as preparing breakfast and cleaning the house. Her job is selling churros (a kind of fried doughnut) from a barrow in the street. She’s been running this business for ten years, and all has gone well thanks to the effort that she puts into her work. Lidia needs a loan to buy 20 kilos of flour. (Churros are maD. with flour, and the centre has a filling maD. of condensed milk.) Lidia belongs to Arariwa Association’s “Las Hijas D. Maria” Community Bank. She is grateful for this opportunity to obtain a loan and promises to make the repayments according to the schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy 20 kilos of flour

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga V. is a 68-year-old woman from the coastal town of Binangonan, Rizal Province in the Philippines. At her older age and being single, it is not easy for her to face the difficulty of poverty but through the support of ASHI in her life, she never felt alone in achieving her dreams.


In 2001, Dominga joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc). ASHI means,” To rise up form poverty”. ASHI is an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. When she received her previous loans, she invested the money in buying and selling fishnets and soon hopes to expand the business with more inventory.


Now on her 13th loan, she requested PHP 30,000 pesos as additional working capital for her business. Dominga is optimistic that her business will grow because she already has regular customers requesting orders from her (fish cage owner).


She dreams of having a space in the market where she can sell her inventory of fishnet products. She also dreams of having a successful business that can provide a good life that is far away from poverty and support the needs of her brother and sisters.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her business.

loans.name: Sheila Marie

texts.en:
Sheila Marie S. is from the village of barangay Quirino, Solano, Neuva Vizcaya. She is thirty-six years old. Sheila Marie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Sheila Marie owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising chickens to produce and sell eggs. Sheila Marie has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sheila Marie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sheila Marie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Sheila Marie is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which she will use to expand the size of the shelter for her livestock. This will Sheila Marie's third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the size of the shelter for her livestock

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida A. is from the city of Baras-Baras, Tarlac. She is 41 and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, she has a business selling rice in the local community. Zenaida has had this business for over two years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Zenaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Penda

texts.fr: Penda S. est une femme de 37ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants et responsable de 2 autre qu'on lui a confiés. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de NGOLLAR depuis 8ans et a eu à bénéficier 16 fois de suite de crédit et n'a jamais eu de problème de remboursement. Elle fait un élevage de mouton et de volaille et fait en même temps un petit commerce de légumes. Elle participe à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Penda S. is a 37-year-old lady who is married with 4 children of her own and is responsible for 2 others whom have been entrusted to her care. She has been a member of the Village Bank NGOLLAR for 8 years and has enjoyed 16 consecutive loans without ever having any trouble with repayments. She rears sheep and poultry and runs a small parallel business selling vegetables. She helps to improve her family's quality of life.

Translated from French by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To support her businesses rearing sheep and poultry and selling vegetables

loans.name: Lea

texts.en: Lea G., 40 years old, is engaged in two businesses. The first one is farming, and her second line is selling processed foods. She started venturing in these businesses just this year. She hopes that she will be able to sustain her livelihoods, especially because she is getting all her resources from these to pay the education of her children and buy the daily needs in their home. She would like to apply for a loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and additional processed food to resell.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
This 31-year-old was a business intermediary before he began his small retail business in Bugoba in Mukono. His business now has a longevity span of five years.

W. Moses’ winning calling card during the course of these five years has been his resilience and courage in the face of financial difficulties. With this he has built on his experience, an experience that has played into his hands.

Having gone through this trivial-round mill, Moses is now taking a long view. He is looking at going into a wholesale business. He is widely optimistic on the basis of the 528,300 shillings he makes a month and the fact that he is also applying for this loan. With other businesses like the kiosk and video hall he operates, Moses anticipates his savings will grow.

The purchase of rice and dried beans for his shop is what he is planning to do with this loan money. His three children are all in school and he is happily married.

loans.use: To purchase bags of dried beans and rice for his business

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann S. is from the village of Pinamulaan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 35 years old and is married with 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Ann owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of her income comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Mary Ann has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mary Ann joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Ann has successfully repaid a recent loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Mary Ann has now requested this, her third loan, for 10,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Teresa Jobe

texts.pt:
Teresa Jobe N. nasceu na Província de Inhambane Sul de Moçambique solteira mãe de três filhas com idades compreendidas entre os 19 aos 26 anos todas vão a escola. Fez a 7ª classe não conseguiu concluir devido a falta de condições financeiras, vive na casa do estado e responsabiliza se pelo seu pai que vive em Zavala.

Saiu de Inhambane para o Distrito de Namaacha na Fronteira com a Suazilândia, devido a transferência do seu pai. Trabalha no Governo do Distrito ha a mais de 31 anos é também chefe da localidade, auferindo mensalmente 6.000.00mt que aplica nas despesas da casa e consegue poupar algum de vez em quanto na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros Bancos, este é o segundo empréstimo na Hluvuku e primeiro com kiva no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, ferro e outros) para dar continuidade da sua obra. O empréstimo anterior foi de 10.000,00mt também para a mesma actividade.

 No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para adquirir uma viatura, para ajudar no transporte pessoal.
texts.en:
Teresa Jobe N. was born in Inhambane Province in southern Mozambique. She is a single mother of 3 daughters who are between 19 and 26 years old. All of them go to school. She studied through the 7th grade but was not able to finish due to a lack of financial resources. She lives in government housing and supports her father, who lives in Zavala. Teresa left Inhambane for Namaacha District on the border with Swaziland due to her father's transfer. She has worked for the District government for more than 31 years and is also head of the town. She earns 6,000 MZN each month, which she uses to pay for household expenses. She is able to save some from time to time in her bank account. She has never had loans with other banks. This is her second loan with Hluvuku and her first with Kiva; it has a value of 20,000 MZN, which she plans to use to buy construction material (cement, iron, etc.) in order to continue working on her house. The previous loan of 10,000 MZN was for the same purpose. In the future Teresa would like to request more loans in order to obtain a vehicle for personal use.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction material (cement, iron, etc.)

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en:
Ma. Elena D. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Mabinuligon, Brgy. DSB, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store and pig fattening business. Her husband Federico D., who is 48 years old, works as a carpenter and farmer to earn his living.  He also helps in his wife.  They have four children who are 17 to  21 years old. 

Ma. Elena joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family.  With the help of her past seven cycle loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Elena has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty.

This time, for her 8th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500 to buy piglets and for additional capital so she can continue to save up for the future education of children.  Ma. Elena D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

---------------------------
About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Rolan

texts.en:
Rolan O. is from the village of Talakag in Bukidnon Province. He is 27 years old. Rolan is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Rolan owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing a pedicab service to local community members. A pedicab is operated by a driver who pedals a bicycle connected to a carrier that can contain up to 2 people. Rolan has been engaged in his business for over 3 years, and he earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rolan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rolan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Rolan is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to invest in renovating the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rolan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in renovating his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy building materials and supplies.

loans.name: Manuela Del Socorro

texts.es:
Doña Manuela del Socorro M. es madre soltero habita en el barrio Camilo Ortega desde hace treinta años con su hijo menor, es una señora emprendedor muy trabajadora y con deseos de superación, actualmente tiene su negocio de venta de comida en el mercado Bisne sector comida, los fines de semana tiene se dedica a su otro negocio de comida ubicado en las playas de paso caballo Corinto  
Doña Manuela M. es clienta activa con más de cuatro años de trabajar con créditos en CEPRODEL de los cuales ha cancelado treinta y dos créditos en tiempo y forma demostrando responsabilidad cabe señalar que todos estos créditos son revolvente cada dos meses permitido  mantener mi negocio estable e irme ampliando y mejorando las condiciones
texts.en:
Manuela del Socorro M. is a single mother who has lived in the Camilo Ortega neighborhood for the past 30 years. She has one young son and is a very hard working and entrepreneurial woman with a desire to get ahead. She sells prepared food in the Bisne market’s food section. On the weekends she runs her other food business, located on the Paso Caballo Corinto beach. Manuela M. has been an active client, working with CEPRODEL for more than four years, during which time she has had two prior loans and has demonstrated responsibility in their repayment. These are revolving loans that turn over every month, allowing her business to remain stable and allowing her to expand and improve its conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Ingredients

loans.name: Cholponai's Group

texts.en:
Cholponai T. is the leader of this group. She is twenty-five and married and has a son who is three years old. Cholponai and her husband breed cattle. They started cattle breeding in 2009 with an initial investment of 20,000 KGS. Her income from cattle breeding is around $220 a month. She applied for a loan in order to get access to funds and be able to purchase additional cattle for breeding. In the future, she is planning to complete construction of her house with the profits received from her business.

Group members:

Zhypar A. is forty and married. She has four children: her daughters are two and three years old and her sons are sixteen and one year old. Her elder son goes to school. Her husband is a taxi driver. In 2009, Zhypar started cattle breeding with an initial investment of 20,000 KGS. She wants to increase the number of cattle and therefore she applied for a loan. Also, along with cattle breeding, she sells national souvenirs. In the future, she is planning make capital repairs on her house.

Rosa A. is twenty-seven and married. She has three children: her two daughters are nine and six years old and her son is one year old. Her two daughters go to school and her son is at home. Rosa breeds cattle, sells national souvenirs and provides rooms in her house to tourists for rent. She started cattle breeding with an initial investment of 30,000 KGS and she gets about $220 monthly in the form of income from cattle breeding. She wants to expand her cattle breeding business but she needs more cattle. Unfortunately, she doesn’t have enough funds, so she applied for a loan.
  
Zhamalbek C. is seventy and married. He has three children and all of them are students. His wife is a pensioner. In 2008, he decided to start cattle breeding with an initial investment of 30,000 KGS. Now, he gets approximately $220 a month from cattle breeding. He wants to increase his cattle numbers in order to increase his profits. He doesn’t have enough funds to do that, so he applied for a loan which will help him to purchase additional cattle for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Bayanmunh

texts.en:
Bayanmunh B. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. His oldest, a son, is a monk and attends a buddhist monastery while his two younger daughters, aged 12 and 13, currently study at a secondary school.

All family members help Bayanmunh with his business. He makes wrestling costumes consisting of a tight shoulder vest (zodog) and shorts (shuudag) and sells his products at Narantuul market once a week. He can make two set of costumes per day. He is a very modest, honest and hardworking person and says: "It is nice to sell products I make myself to my customers."

Bayanmunh is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase materials such as fiber strings, leather and padding as well as to buy a new sewing machine which all will help him continue making traditional wrestling costumes.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine and materials for making more traditional wrestling costumes

loans.name: Luis Miguel

texts.es: El señor Luis Miguel es una persona muy dedicada al bienestar de su familia, el y su esposa la señora Azucena, trabajan en una maquiladora todo el día, tienen dos hijos pequeños y los dejan al cuidado de la mama de la señora Azucena, no están en todo el día en su casa, la cual tienen poco con ella, ya que la adquirieron de interés social. Ellos necesitan mucho el dinero por que hace pocos días entraron unas personas a robar en su vivienda, y por esto quieren construir una barda en la parte trasera de la vivienda. Ellos temen por su seguridad y la de sus hijos, y agradecen su enorme ayuda.
texts.en:
Luis Miguel is a person who is dedicated to his family’s wellbeing. He and his wife, Azucena, work in a maquiladora (assembly plant) all day. They have two small children that they leave in Azucena’s mother’s care. They are away from home all day. They have owned their house for just a short period of time. They purchased it through a low-income, government subsidized loan program. They need the funds very much because recently people broke into their home to steal. They want to build a wall on the rear of the property. They fear for their children’s safety and are grateful for this enormous help.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a wall.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina C. is from the village of Bato. She is 54 years old. Regina is single. To make a living, Regina owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Regina has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Regina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Regina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Regina is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 14th loan taken out by Regina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Amartuvshin

texts.en: Amartuvshin G. is 36 years old and lives with his wife in Hovd province of Mongolia. He and his wife live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Amartuvshin operates a clothing store in his town. He started his business in 2007 with working capital that was given to him by his parents. Over the years, he has built a stable and successful operation and his earnings have enabled him to buy a new car that is used as a taxi. Moreover, he has used his earnings to start building a new house in his yard which is not completed yet. He and his wife operate a taxi service to supplement their family income. His current working capital has decreased because of buying the new car, therefore he needs more funds in order to increase his working capital to purchase more clothes to sell. Amartuvshin is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to import more winter clothing from China to sell.

loans.use: To import more winter clothing

loans.name: Kahaso

texts.en:
Kahaso is a married woman with seven children, six of whom attend school, while one is too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, school fees and clothing. 

She operates a vegetables stall at the market, selling green vegetables and potatoes to her neighbours and passersby. Kahaso faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to improve her business and repair her house in the future.

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase more sacks of green vegetables and potatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of green vegetables and potatoes

loans.name: Yin

texts.en:
Yin O. is 52 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in the busy local market for more than nine years. She sells fish that she buys from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen. She was married, but divorced her husband when her children were very young. She now lives with her three children who also sell fish. 

Yin O. runs her business well because she has public relations skills that she uses with her customers. Yin O. wishes to have more funds to increase her capital, which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a loan from Kiva to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Luis Ernesto

texts.es:
Luis reside en Jiquilisco, departamento de Usulután, tiene 29 años de edad, vive con su madre y esposa, es empleado de una empresa financiera desde hace 1 año. Por su trabajo el sale a las afueras y se le hace difícil por la falta de transporte, situación que le lleva a solicitar un préstamo para comprar una motocicleta, este préstamo le ayudara a adquirir este medio de transporte que el tanto necesita para desarrollar las actividades que su trabajo le demanda.
